questions.text: Select the drug which acts through Tyrosine Kinase receptor.
questions.solution:
Tyrosine kinase receptors are integral components of the insulin signaling pathway. They are transmembrane proteins that bind and respond to insulin in the bloodstream, transducing the signal across the cell membrane and into the cell itself. Upon insulin binding to the receptor, the intrinsic tyrosine kinase activity is activated and the receptor autophosphorylates, resulting in the recruitment of adaptor proteins that further activate multiple downstream signaling pathways that regulate many cellular metabolic processes. This ultimately results in the cellular uptake of glucose, essential for maintaining an adequate glucose homeostasis. The tyrosine kinase receptor plays a pivotal role in insulin's mechanism of action, as it is essential for transducing the extracellular signal across the membrane and for regulating the intracellular metabolic processes that enable the cellular uptake of glucose.
 

1. Nuclear receptors- Sex hormones 
2. Cell membrane receptors- GPCR or Tyrosine Kinase receptors 

  •  Tyrosine Kinase - Remember PIG - Prolactin, Insulin, GH
  • GPCR - remaining vast majority of hormones (Non PIG)


Reference- Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology Edition 26 th Page no 55

choices.text: Thiazide act as an add-on to Lithium
Thiazide increases the tubular reabsorption of Sodium, decreasing Lithium secretion.
Thiazide cause loss of water thereby increasing Lithium levels

questions.text: A patient with bipolar disorder was started on Thiazides for hypertension. After a couple of days, he developed coarse tremors. Likely reason is:
questions.solution:
Correct option: 3. Thiazide increases the tubular reabsorption of Sodium, decreasing Lithium secretion.
 
  • The likely reason for the development of coarse tremors in a patient with bipolar disorder who was started on Thiazides for hypertension is decreased Lithium secretion due to increased compensatory proximal tubular reabsorption of sodium due to the thiazide use.
  •  Thiazides are known to decrease the renal clearance of Lithium, which can lead to an increase in Lithium levels in the blood. This effect is due to the fact that Thiazides increase the excretion of Sodium in the kidneys at DCT, leading to increased Sodium reabsorption at PCT and decreased Lithium secretion.
  • This can cause Lithium toxicity, which can present with symptoms such as coarse tremors.


Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page no 477.

questions.text: Select the drug from the given graph which has the highest potency.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (option 1) Drug A

The Dose Response Curve (DRC) on the X axis defines the potency of a drug. The further left the DRC is positioned on the X axis, the more potent the drug is. In the graph provided, the DRC of Drug A is to the far left, indicating that Drug A is the most potent of the three drugs. This means that the potency of Drug A is greater than B and C.

The position of DRC on the dose axis is the index of drug potency which refers to the amount of drug needed to produce a certain response. 
The upper limit of DRC is the index of drug efficacy and refers to the maximal response that can be elicited by the drug.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 64.

questions.text: What amongst the following is not the mechanism of resistance to penicillin ?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) Alteration in 50S ribosome structure

The three main mechanisms of bacterial resistance to the β-lactam antibiotics are
(i) enzymatic degradation by β-lactamases,
(ii) target modification of the PBPs resulting in a lack of β-lactam binding, and
(iii) regulation of β-lactam entry and efflux.

Penicillin is a bacterial cell wall synthesis inhibitor so it is not related to 50S ribosome.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 767.

questions.text: Pick the drug which acts by inhibiting DNA transcription.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Actinomycin D
 
  • Actinomycin D is an antibacterial agent and a type of antibiotic that inhibits the transcription of DNA into RNA.
  • It does this by binding to the double-stranded DNA helix and blocking the enzyme RNA polymerase from transcribing the genes for protein synthesis.
  • This prevents the cell from being able to translate the DNA into proteins, which halts the growth and replication of the cell. In this way, Actinomycin D is used to stop DNA replication and to inhibit the expression of certain genes.
Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 926

questions.text: Select the assessment procedure when a patient with Li therapy for bipolar disorder for 6 months keeps religious fasting for a few days and shows S3, coarse tremors, confusion and weakness of limbs.
questions.solution:
In a patient with lithium therapy for bipolar disorder who has been fasting for a few days and is now presenting with symptoms such as S3, coarse tremors, confusion, and weakness of limbs, the most important assessment procedure is to measure the patient's serum lithium levels. Therefore, the correct answer is option 2 (S. Li levels).

Lithium toxicity is a potential complication of lithium therapy, and fasting can increase the risk of toxicity due to changes in renal function and electrolyte imbalances. Symptoms of lithium toxicity may include tremors, confusion, weakness, and cardiac abnormalities such as S3 sounds. Therefore, monitoring serum lithium levels is crucial in patients receiving lithium therapy, especially when there are changes in medication or diet.

While an ECG (option 3) may help to identify any cardiac abnormalities associated with lithium toxicity, it is not the most important assessment in this scenario. S. Electrolyte (option 1) levels may also be helpful to evaluate the patient's electrolyte status and renal function, but serum lithium levels are the most critical assessment. An MRI (option 4) is not indicated in this scenario, as it is not useful in evaluating lithium toxicity.

questions.text: Mention the drug used as nail lacquer for fungal infections.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) Ciclopirox
 
  • Ciclopirox is an antifungal medication used to treat fungal infections of the skin and nails.
  • It is often used to treat onychomycosis, which is a fungal infection of the toenails or fingernails.
  • Ciclopirox works by stopping the growth of the fungi and preventing it from spreading.
  • Additionally, it helps to restore the natural color and texture of the affected nails. This can reduce the discoloration and thickness of fungal-infected nails, allowing for them to grow normally.
  • Another antifungal used as nail laquer is Amrolfine. 
Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 848.

questions.text: The drug Pegloticase is used to treat which of the following diseases
questions.solution:
Correct option: 3. Chronic tophaceous gout
 
  • Pegloticase is a biologic therapy specifically for the treatment of chronic gout in adults who have not responded to traditional therapy.
  • It works by breaking down the urate crystals in the joints that cause gout pain and stiffness.
  • Pegloticase was approved by the U.S. Food and Drug Administration in September 2010.
  • Pegloticase is administered as an intravenous (IV) infusion every two weeks and is gradually broken down by the body over two to three days.
  • It reduces the levels of excess uric acid in the blood, allowing the body to dissolve or flush out the urate crystals that have built up in the joints over time. This helps reduce pain, swelling and stiffness associated with gout.
  • It can also help to improve mobility and range of motion by decreasing inflammation of the joints.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2865.

questions.text: Pick the one which is not a prokinetic.
Select the drug for the condition where a developed pain and insect crawling-like sensation on legs at night relieved by shaking her legs.
questions.solution:
Restless Leg Syndrome (RLS) is a neurological disorder that occurs when someone feels an uncontrollable urge to move their legs. It is most commonly characterized by an intense tingling or crawling sensation in the legs, which can be relieved temporarily by moving or stretching the legs. Symptoms are often worse in the evening and can interfere with sleep and daily activities. RLS is thought to be caused by an imbalance of dopamine in the part of the brain responsible for body movements. Treatment options include lifestyle changes, medications, therapy, and in severe cases, surgery. 

Iron tablets are the first line drugs for its management.

questions.text: Choose the fluoroquinolone that shouldn't be used in liver d/s.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Pefloxacin
 
  • Pefloxacin is contraindicated in liver disease because it is metabolized in the liver and can cause function to decrease further, causing serious health issues.
  • This includes increased levels of toxicity and a risk of liver failure. Taking Pefloxacin in this instance can increase the likelihood of serious adverse reactions and, in some cases, death.
  • Moxifloxacin & Pefloxacin are the FQs metabolised in Liver (MoPed by Liver)
Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 746.

questions.text: What amongst the following treatment shouldn't be used when a person starts feeling breathlessness at a high altitude of 3000 m
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario is of Mountain Sickness. When a person starts feeling breathlessness at a high altitude of 3000 m, the most appropriate treatment would be to initiate immediate descent to a lower altitude. Oxygen supplementation (option 2) can be used to treat altitude sickness and improve oxygenation. Acetazolamide (option 4) can be used for the prevention and treatment of altitude sickness. Acetazolamide works by promoting respiratory alkalosis, which can lead to increased ventilation and oxygenation.

 I/V digoxin (option 1) is not indicated for the treatment of altitude sickness and may cause adverse effects such as arrhythmias and cardiac toxicity. Hence  IV digoxin should not be used in this given scenario.


Reference- Ganong’s Review of Medical Physiology Edition 26 th Page no 638

questions.text:
What amongst the following is a fact about non-competitive inhibition?
1. km remains same, Vmax decrease
2. km increase, Vmax increase
3. km decrease, Vmax increase
4. km increase, Vmax increases
questions.solution:
Noncompetitive inhibition is a type of enzyme inhibition in which the activity of the enzyme is not affected by the substrate concentration but is instead modified by another compound (inhibitor). The inhibitor binds to the enzyme at a site other than that of the substrate, which alters the shape of the active site in such a way that it cannot bind the substrate or binds it with substantially lower affinity. Noncompetitive inhibition does not affect the Km, or the Michaelis constant, of the enzyme for the substrate, but does decreases the Vmax, the maximum reaction rate for a given enzyme concentration.

Trick : -
KiVu- Kmax increase, Vmax unchanged- Competitive
KuVr- Kmax unchanged, Vmax reduced- Non competitive


Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 31st Edition, Page no 77.

questions.text: Under what condition does Theophylline cause diuresis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Adenosine A1 receptor antagonism

  • Remember TEA - Theophylline - Enzyme inhibitor (PDE) - Adenosine A1 Receptor inhibitor, and is found in tea and coffee
  • Because of PDE inhibition - smooth muscle relaxation - Bronchodialation occurs - hence can be used in the treatment of status asthmaticus
  • Theophylline is an Adenosine receptor antagonist, meaning it blocks the binding of adenosine, a neurotransmitter, to A1 and A2a receptors located throughout the body. 
  • The A1 receptor is expressed in the proximal tubule and stimulates reabsorption of Na+. Consequently, antagonists of A1 receptors cause diuresis/natriuresis.
  • S/E due to Adenosine A1 R antagonism - Insomnia, seizures, tachypnea, tachycardia, Diuresis, Nausea and Vomiting (most common)

Option 1, 4 PDE3 and PDE4 are likely account for the bronchodilator action of theophylline which is involve in PDE inhibition and the concomitant elevation of cellular cAMP and cyclic GMP.
Option 3 there is no B2 agonist action of Theophylline.

Reference: Goodman & Gilman’s the Pharmacological Basis of Therapeutics, 14th edition, Page No 572.

questions.text: Choose the treatment to relieve a patient with COPD who developed postoperative urinary retention.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) Tamsulosin

While Bethenechol as a muscarinic agonist is typically used for the management of Post-operative urinary retention - its use is contraindicated in COPD/Asthma since it would worsen the bronchospasm.
Tamsulosin - an alpha-1a receptor antagonist which relaxes the bladder muscle is the most appropriate treatment.

Option 2 and 3 have no use in postoperative urinary retention

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 156.

questions.text: Select the drug of choice for invasive aspergillosis.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Voriconazole

  • Invasive aspergillosis is an infection caused by the fungi sinus Aspergillus. It can cause severe respiratory problems, especially in those with weakened immune systems or whose lungs have already been damaged.
  • Symptoms of the disease include fever, coughing, chest pain, difficulty breathing and a decreased appetite. The spreading fungal infection can cause more serious health complications, such as organ damage, pulmonary embolism and even death.
  • Management for invasive aspergillosis depends upon how severe the infection is. Preventive measures can be taken for those at a higher risk, such as administering antifungal prophylaxis, avoiding immunosuppression when possible, and resolving any risk factors, such as smoking cessation, good hygiene, and prompt removal of any organic material that could encourage fungal growth.
    When the infection has become invasive and severe, the typical treatment is intravenous administration of the antifungal drug, voriconazole.
  • This drug is preferred due to its efficacy and relatively low cost, making it the drug of choice for invasive aspergillosis. It is also available in oral, breathing treatments and intrathecal forms for those who cannot tolerate intravenous medication. Amphotericin B is usually used as a secondary therapy when the infection does not respond to voriconazole.
  • Other drugs, such as caspofungin, posaconazole, and itraconazole, are also available as second-line treatments. It is advised that multiple drugs are used in combination therapy to increase the efficacy of treatment.


Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 846.

questions.text: Pick the antihypertensive drug avoided in patients with high serum uric acid levels.
questions.solution:
Hydrochlorothiazide increases uric acid levels.
 
  • Mechanism: first, the thiazide enters the proximal tubule cell, and then is exchanged with uric acid, driving the reabsorption of urate.
 
  • Long-term use of higher dose thiazides in hypertension has caused rise in blood urate level.
 
  • It tends to raise blood uric acid level by competing with its proximal tubular secretion as well as by increasing reabsorption in PT that occurs as a consequence of reduced e.c.f. volume.


Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page no 627, 632.

questions.text: Select the drug which acts by preventing the transcription of DNA to RNA slowly.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Rifampicin
 
  • Rifampicin binds to the beta subunit of the DNA- dependent RNA polymerase and inhibits RNA synthesis in the bacteria. It is bactericidal.
  • In therapeutic concentrations, rifampicin cannot bind human RNA polymerase and it, therefore, selectively destroys the bacteria.
  • Moreover, it reaches the cavities, caseous material and penetrates macrophages.
Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 818.

questions.text: What is the initial drug for the management of a patient who recently started on Fluphenazine and after a few weeks developed tremors, rigidity, bradykinesia, and excessive salivation
questions.solution:
Correct option: 2. Trihexyphenidyl
 
  • Tremors, rigidity, and bradykinesia point towards Drug-induced Parkinsonism which is an extrapyramidal side effect observed with Antipsychotic (anti-dopaminergic) drugs like Fluphenazine.
  • Trihexyphenidyl is an anti-cholinergic medication used to manage the neurological adverse reactions associated with the use of antipsychotic (anti-dopaminergic) drugs such as fluphenazine.
  • It helps to reduce these symptoms, providing relief and allowing patients to continue on the antipsychotic course without interruption.


Reference: Kaplan and Sadock's Concise Textbook of Clinical Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page no 924.
Goodman & Gillman's The Pharmacological Basis of Therapeutics, 13th edition, Page no 282.

questions.text: Pick from the option the  antimicrobial which shouldn't be given to a c/c asthmatic patient being managed on theophylline therapy.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Erythromycin

  • Erythromycin and theophylline should not be given together because they can cause serious drug interactions.
  • Erythromycin is a strong inhibitor of cytochrome P450-3A4 enzyme, which is responsible for the metabolism of theophylline.
  • When taken together, erythromycin will inhibit the action of cytochrome P450-3A4 and cause an elevation of theophylline levels in the blood, leading to the risk of theophylline toxicity.


Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 246.

questions.text: Select the drug used for reversal of muscle relaxation after surgery on a person who has been treated with a muscle relaxant that blocks nicotinic receptors.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Neostigmine

  • Neostigmine is a reversible anticholinesterase, meaning it is an enzyme that blocks the action of the enzyme acetylcholinesterase (AchE) which is involved in the breakdown of acetylcholine (Ach). By preventing the breakdown of Ach, Neostigmine increases the amount of Ach available at the postsynaptic cleft and postsynaptic membrane, enhancing cholinergic neurotransmission at the skeletal muscle endplate, and restoring normal muscle tone. This makes Neostigmine ideal for use in the reversal of anesthesia/postoperative decurarization. 
  • Physostigmine is a tertiary amine so it crosses BBB hence is not preferred. It is used in closed angle glaucoma.
  • However, Neostigmine can cause unwanted side effects, such as nausea and excess salivation, which can be prevented by the use of an anti-muscarinic drug such as Atropine and Glycopyrrolate. By combining these two types of medications, it is possible to successfully reverse anesthesia/postoperative decurarization without the risk of side effects.


Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 122.

questions.text: What is the anti-glaucoma drug which acts by increasing uveoscleral outflow?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Latanoprost

  • Latanoprost is a prostaglandin analogue that works to reduce intraocular pressure by increasing the outflow of aqueous humour from the eyes. By relaxing the eye muscles around the drainage angle, it reduces the blockage of aqueous humour that can lead to increased intraocular pressure. This is done by converting to a biologically active form of prostaglandin, specifically to prostaglandin F2α (PGF2α), within the eye. Once PGF2α is formed within the eye, it acts to open the trabecular meshwork within the drainage angle, which then causes the aqueous humour to flow out of the eye at a faster and more efficient rate.
  • This increased outflow helps reduce the elevated pressure levels within the eye and brings it back to within the normal range. Additionally, PGF2α also works by decreasing the amount of aqueous humour that is produced. This combination of increased outflow and decreased production of aqueous humour helps to control the IOP levels and bring them to within the normal range.


* Other options: -

Option 2- Timolol is a beta antagonist which acts by decreasing aqueous production.
Option 3- Pilocarpine is a cholinergic drug which acts by increasing trabecular outflow.
Option 4- Dorzolamide is a carbonic anhydrase inhibitor acts by decreasing aqueous production.
 

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 168, 169.

questions.text: A patient diagnosed with Rheumatoid arthritis was on medications. Which drug is responsible to cause blurring vision and corneal opacity post 2 years of medication?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Chloroquine

  • For RA, Chloroquine has to be given for long periods accumulate in tissues (especially melanin containing tissue) and produce toxicity, particularly in the eyes.
  • These include retinopathy, blurred or distorted vision, loss of central vision, Corneal Opacity and difficulty seeing in dim light.
  • In some cases, long-term use of chloroquine can lead to irreversible retinal damage and a condition known as pigmentary maculopathy, which can cause a permanent loss of vision.
Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 229.

questions.text: Pick the drug which would prevent motion sickness in a person who is planning to travel by bus.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Promethazine

  • Promethazine is a first-line medication for the prevention and treatment of motion sickness. It is generally effective for preventing nausea and vomiting due to motion. It works by blocking dopamine, a neurotransmitter that helps regulate nausea.
  • It also has antihistamine properties that can help provide relief from symptoms of motion sickness such as dizziness, irritability and headache.
  • In addition, it is a sedative and calming agent, which can help to relieve anxiety associated with motion sickness.
* Other options: 

Option 2 Meclizine- It is also a first generation antihistaminic used in prevention of motion sickness but it is not as effective as promethazine 
Option 3 and 4 They are second generation antihistaminic therefore can't cross BBB and not effective in motion sickness.


Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 183.

questions.text: Select the antiarrhythmic drug which needs to be avoided in a patient with Interstitial lung diseases
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Amiodarone
 
  • Amiodarone is a drug used to treat arrhythmias and is associated with a number of dose dependent pulmonary side effects, including interstitial lung disease (ILD), Pulmonary alveolitis and fibrosis.
  • The most serious adverse effect during chronic amiodarone therapy is pulmonary fibrosis, which can be rapidly progressive and fatal.
  • Underlying lung disease, doses of 400 mg/d or more, and recent pulmonary insults such as pneumonia, ILD appear to be risk factors.
  • Thus, Amiodarone needs to be avoided in a patient with Interstitial lung diseases.
  • Serial chest X-rays or pulmonary function studies may detect early amiodarone toxicity but monitoring plasma concentrations has not been useful.
  • With low doses, such as 200 mg/d or less as used in AF, pulmonary toxicity is less common.
Option 2, 3 and 4 Drugs doesn't have any known contraindication to be used in a patient of ILD
 

Drugs that can cause lung fibrosis (drug-induced interstitial lung disease) include:

Category Examples
Chemotherapeutics Bleomycin, Busulfan, Methotrexate, Cyclophosphamide
Antiarrhythmics Amiodarone
Antibiotics Nitrofurantoin, Sulfasalazine
Biologics TNF-alpha inhibitors (e.g., Etanercept, Infliximab)
Immunosuppressants Sirolimus, Everolimus

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 578.

questions.text: Name the principal late inward sodium channel blocker.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Ranolazine
 
  • Ranolazine is a late inward sodium channel blocker, meaning that it can be used to reduce the influx of sodium ions into the cell by blocking the late inward sodium currents.
  • This property can be used to prevent arrhythmias, as excessive influx of sodium can lead to abnormal electrical signals that trigger arrhythmia.
  • Furthermore, ranolazine can reduce the excitability of the ventricular myocardium, decreasing heart rate and lowering the amount of oxygen used by the heart. This can help reduce the symptoms of angina and reduce the risk of ischemic heart failure.
Trick:-
RaNolazine- Na+ channel blocker

Option 1 Ivabradine is a selective blocker of hyperpolarization-activated cyclic nucleotide–gated (HCN) ion channels involved in the generation of automaticity in the SA node.
Option 3 Trimetazidine is a partial fatty acid oxidase (PFOX) inhibitor that prevents cardiac tissue from oxidizing free fatty acids (major source of ATP in heart).
Option 4 Fasudil is a selective RhoA/Rho kinase (ROCK) inhibitor that appears to reduce pulmonary artery pressure in PAH.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 600.

questions.text: What injection amongst the following was given to a patient of biliary colic which worsened the pain?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Morphine
 
  • Morphine is an opioid drug that is often used to treat pain.
  • In the case of biliary colic, however, morphine can worsen the pain because of the bile duct spasm that can cause constriction of sphincter of oddi and lead to increased billiary pressure to 10 folds, which can lead to an increase in pain. 

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 502.

questions.text: What is the next step in management for a full-term baby with a birth weight of 2700g and on day 5 of life has bilirubin of 9-10 mg/dl.
questions.solution:
The correct option is option (3) -Normal newborn care.

In term neonates, physiologic jaundice typically peaks between day 3–5, with bilirubin levels around 10–12 mg/dL (can go up to 15 mg/dL in some cases). This infant’s bilirubin (9–10 mg/dL) is within the normal physiological range and no risk factors (prematurity, hemolysis, sepsis, cholestasis) are mentioned in the question. 

Hence, this serum bilirubin level is normal and indicates that the neonate has a physiological form of jaundice, which is expected in newborns. This child does not require any intervention and normal newborn care (option 3) should be continued. 

According to AAP, below are the Phototherapy/DVET cutoff values for bilirubin- above which PT/DVET should be given

Child's Bilirubin( 9-10mg/dL) is well below the cutoffs and hence, child does not require any Phototherapy (option 2) or Double volume exchange transfusion (option 1)
 

Reference-Ghai Essential Pediatrics 9th Edition Page no 168-172

questions.text: Select the muscle marked in the given image.
questions.solution:
The Levator scapulae muscle is a triangular muscle in the neck and upper back region. It connects the neck to the shoulder blade and helps lift the shoulder blade when you shrug your shoulders. The Dorsal scapular nerve (C5) is the nerve that provides sensation and motor control to the Levator scapulae muscle.


 

Reference: Gray's Anatomy The Anatomical Basis Of Clinical Practice Edition 42 nd Page no 843

questions.text: Mention the anatomical structure that prevents the upward extension of thyroid swelling which is attached to the thyroid cartilage.
questions.solution:
Sternothyroid muscle > pre-tracheal fascia Both pre-tracheal fascia and sternothyroid muscle prevent the upward extension of thyroid swelling. As per Snell's Clinical Anatomy "Attachment of sternothyroid muscle to thyroid cartilage effectively limits the upward extension of Thyroid gland".


 

Reference: Gray's Anatomy The Anatomical Basis Of Clinical Practice Edition 42 nd Page no 601-603

questions.text: Select the joint type shown in the red circle in the image.
questions.solution:
• The red circle shows a Costovertebral joint
  • They are formed by the articulation of articular facets on the head of ribs and costal facets on the bodies of thoracic vertebrae. These joints are a type of plane synovial joint and it allows slight gliding movements, which contribute to the flexibility of the rib cage during respiration. They provide stability to the spine as well. 
 

Reference: Gray's Anatomy The Anatomical Basis Of Clinical Practice Edition 42 nd Page no 102,103,299

questions.text: Where does meiosis take place in the human cell?
questions.solution:
The meiosis is a type of cell division that takes place only in the reproductive organs to produce haploid gametes. Gametogenesis in males, known as spermatogenesis, begins with primordial germ cells, or PCs, that remain dormant until puberty in the seminiferous tubules of the testes. At this point, the seminiferous tubules mature and the PCs undergo a series of mitotic divisions to form spermatogonia. These spermatogonia then produce primary spermatocytes, and each of these primary spermatocytes will undergo Meiosis I and Meiosis II to form four spermatids. The result of this meiotic process is the production of haploid gametes which can then be used for sexual reproduction.

In adult ovaries meiosis 1 is completed and secondary oocysts are formed which stay in metaphase 2 after ovulation. Hence option 2 is the correct option. 

 

References - Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology Edition 26 th Page no390

questions.text: Select the artery thrombosis that can lead to a patient presenting with clinical features of vertigo, nystagmus.
questions.solution:
Obstruction of the superior cerebellar artery (SCA), located more rostrally, tends to produce more ataxia, dysarthria, and nystagmus, with less frequent vertigo, headache, and vomiting occurrences.
Obstruction of SCA causes Lateral superior pontine syndrome (a.k.a syndrome of superior cerebellar artery)
Clinical features of Syndrome of SCA:

On side of lesion
  • Ataxia of limbs and gait, falling to side of lesion: Middle and superior cerebellar peduncles, superior surface of cerebellum, dentate nucleus
  • Dizziness, nausea, vomiting; horizontal nystagmus: Vestibular nucleus
  • Paresis of conjugate gaze (ipsilateral): Pontine contralateral gaze
  • Skew deviation: Uncertain
  • Miosis, ptosis, decreased sweating over face (Horner’s syndrome): Descending sympathetic fibers
  • Tremor: Localization unclear—Dentate nucleus, superior cerebellar peduncle
On side opposite lesion
  • Impaired pain and thermal sense on face, limbs, and trunk: Spinothalamic tract
  • Impaired touch, vibration, and position sense, more in leg than arm (there is a tendency to incongruity of pain and touch deficits): Medial lemniscus (lateral portion)



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 3332.

questions.text: The reason for the long left recurrent laryngeal N. is due to the persistence of which arch artery
Which group of muscles given below are affected in claw hand?
questions.solution:
The claw hand presented here is a condition in which the intrinsic muscles of the hand are affected. These muscles are primarily supplied by the ulnar nerve, which is also known as the nerve of fine movements. The median nerve supplies some of the intrinsic muscles through its recurrent branch (1st and 2nd lumbricals, and thenar group of muscles, except for the deep head of the flexor pollicis brevis). The anterior interosseous nerve, which is a branch of the median nerve, does not supply any of the intrinsic muscles of the hand. Similarly, the radial nerve and its branch, the posterior interosseous nerve, do not supply any of the intrinsic muscles of the hand.




Reference-: Ebnezar's Textbook of Orthopedics 5th Edition Page no 62

questions.text: The ligation of the common hepatic artery impair blood supply to which arteries
questions.solution:
Ligation of the common hepatic artery will impair blood supply in the right gastric and right gastroepiploic arteries because the common hepatic artery is the main supply of blood to both arteries. Without it, blood flow to the two arteries will be significantly reduced, decreasing the oxygen and nutrient supply to the organs they supply, potentially leading to tissue death.





 

Reference: Gray's Anatomy The Anatomical Basis Of Clinical Practice Edition 42 nd Page no 1464.e74,1464.e75,1168

questions.text: 50y old male presents with loss of sensation over the right side of face and sensory symtoms over left side of the body. What is the most likely localisation of the lesion?
questions.solution:
Lateral medullary infarction (also known as Wallenberg syndrome) is a stroke that occurs when one of the Vertebral artery > Posterior Inferior Cerebellar Artery that supply blood to the medulla oblongata in the brain is suddenly blocked.
Symptoms of the syndrome typically include unconsciousness, dizziness, vertigo, nausea, Ipsilateral ataxia, bulbar palsy, loss of temperature and pain sensation of face and contralateral loss of pain and temperature in body.


Reference-: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 20th Edition Page no 3329

questions.text: Locate the structure given.
questions.solution:
The arrow points toawrds Purkinje Cells. (characterized by its flask shaped structurebranching dendrites seen) The histology of the grey matter of the cerebellum consists of an outer molecular layer, a middle Purkinje layer, and an inner granule cell layer. The molecular layer contains small neurons such as stellate cells and basket cells Purkinje layer contains a single layer of flask-shaped Purkinje cells with branching dendrites. The granule cell layer consists of small granule cells, large Golgi type II cells, and glomeruli.


Reference: Gray’s Anatomy The Anatomical Basis Of Clinical Practice Edition 42 nd Page no 475,476

questions.text: Select the vessel affected by tumor of the uncinate process of pancreas.
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1. Superior mesenteric artery
 
  • The uncinate process is a thin, curved projection at the lower and medial aspect of the head of the pancreas that passes between the superior mesenteric artery and the abdominal aorta.
  • This structure divides the superior mesenteric vessels anteriorly and the abdomen posteriorly and can be seen on sagittal cross-sectional imaging.
  • The uncinate process can potentially be compressed by a tumor at this site and may lead to compression of the superior mesenteric vessels with resulting effects on blood flow.

Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 1286.

questions.text: A man was brought to the emergency after meeting with an accident and injured his perineum. He gets an urge to micturate but its unable to pass urine. On examination blood was seen at tip of urethra and swelling of penis and scrotum. Locate the site of injury among the following:
questions.solution:
A ruptured bulbar urethra is an injury that occurs when there is severe blunt force trauma to the pelvis or groin area. Symptoms include perineal bruising and hematoma, bleeding from the urethral meatus, and difficulty passing urine. Diagnosis is typically confirmed through urethrography using a water-soluble contrast agent. Initial management involves inserting a suprapubic catheter to drain the bladder, in order to reduce the chance of urinary extravasation and sepsis in the perineal hematoma. In more severe cases, delayed urethroplasty is typically done as the definitive treatment.



Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery 28th Edition Page no: 1520,1540-1

questions.text: Name the cartilage shown in the image below .
questions.solution:
Elastic cartilage, also known as yellow fibrocartilage, is similar in many ways to hyaline cartilage. It contains a semi-rigid mesh of collagen fibres in its extracellular matrix and provides structure and flexibility to tissue. However, the collagen fibres in elastic cartilage are interwoven with numerous elastic fibres, forming a network. This elastic matrix gives elastic cartilage the capacity to bear tension and return to its original shape after being stretched or compressed. The elastic fibres are not visible in regular hematoxylin and eosin-stained sections, and require special staining techniques such as resorcin, fusion and orcein to make them visible.

Examples of elastic cartilage: - pinna, epiglottis.


Reference: Gray’s Anatomy The Anatomical Basis Of Clinical Practice Edition 42 nd Page no 88

questions.text: Which part of the fallopian tube does fertilisation occur?
questions.solution:
Fertilisation occurs in the Ampulla of fallopian tube.







Reference: Williams Obstetrics, 26th edition, Page no 85.

questions.text: Pick the remnant of Wolffian duct in a female.
questions.solution:
The mesonephric duct is an embryonic structure that develops during fetal growth and eventually disappears in both sexes. In some people, however, part of it may persist as a structure known as a Gartner duct cyst. These cysts can be found between the layers of the broad ligament along the lateral wall of the uterus and in the wall of the vagina. They are typically filled with fluid and can range in size from a few millimeters to several centimeters. They do not usually cause any symptoms, however they can be painful if they become large enough to press against other structures.




 

Reference: Gray's Anatomy The Anatomical Basis Of Clinical Practice Edition 42 nd Page no 353

questions.text: Pick the immediate posterior structure injured when episiotomy is extended posteriorly beyond the perineal body.
questions.solution:
Correct option: 1. External anal sphincter
 
  • When an episiotomy is extended, it can inadvertently cut or tear through the external anal sphincter and other structures along the posterior wall of the perineum.
  • The external anal sphincter is particularly vulnerable because it is a thin, circular muscle located near the opening of the anus, and it is particularly susceptible to damage during a surgical procedure.
  • Additionally, trauma to the external anal sphincter can cause permanent dysfunction and affect the ability of the patient to control her bowel movements and reduce the quality of life.



Reference: Shaw's Textbook of Gynaecology, 17th edition, Page no 399, 400.

questions.text: Which of the following is a cause of oligohydramnios when a woman with 18 weeks gestation presented to the OPD with uterine size 16 weeks:
questions.solution:
Correct option: 1. Renal agenesis

Fetal and Maternal Causes of Oligohydramnios: 

Fetal Conditions:
• Spontaneous rupture of the membranes
• Premature rupture of the membranes
• Abnormal placentation-elevated MSAFP/MSHCG
• Renal agenesis or obstructed uropathy
• Postmaturity syndrome etc.

Maternal Conditions: 
• Antiphospholipid syndrome
• Dehydration-hypovolemia
• Hypertensive disorders
• Uteroplacental insufficiency
• Idiopathic etc.

*MSAFP = maternal serum alpha-fetoprotein, MSHCG=maternal serum human chorionic gonadotropin



Reference: Williams Obstetrics, 26th edition, Page no 260, 298.
DC Dutta's Textbook of Obstetrics, 9th edition, Page no 203.

questions.text: What is the most likely diagnosis for a child with evisceration of bowel loops coming out of a defect in the abdominal wall right to the umbilicus
questions.solution:
Gastroschisis is a birth defect that results in the intestines and sometimes other organs, such as the stomach, liver, and spleen, protruding outside the baby's body. It is a congenital defect that usually occurs in the abdominal wall to the right of the umbilicus. In many cases, the abdominal wall may not fully form, leaving a hole or an “omphalocele.” The cause of gastroschisis is unknown. Most fetuses with gastroschisis have normal intelligence, growth, and development. Noted symptoms for gastroschisis include the protrusion of the baby’s internal organs from the body, abdominal wall defects (omphalocele), umbilical hernia, and small bowel/intestine prolapse. Babies with gastroschisis commonly have bowel obstruction and can also have other systemic defects such as cardiac and genitourinary anomalies. Treatment includes physical therapy and, if necessary, surgical correction.



 

Reference: Langman' Medical Embryology Edition 14 th page no 382,383,401

questions.text: Pick the tetanus prophylaxis for a 39 years old man met with a clean wound without laceration reporting after 4 hours who took TT vaccination 10 years ago.
questions.solution:
Guide to Tetanus Prophylaxis Immunisation status Clean wound Tetanus prone wound Fully immunised (5 doses of tetanus vaccine at appropriate intervals) Nil No vaccine required unless > 10 years since previous vaccine Consider TIG* Primary immunisation and age appropriate boosters complete Nil Nil Consider TIG* Primary immunisation or age appropriate boosters incomplete Age appropriate tetanus vaccine and complete vaccine schedule Age appropriate tetanus vaccine and complete vaccine schedule TIG Unimmunised or unknown vaccine status Age appropriate tetanus vaccine and complete vaccine schedule Age appropriate tetanus vaccine and complete vaccine schedule TIG * Consider TIG in fully vaccinated patients who are immunocompromised such as • Patients with primary immunodeficiency, asplenia or HIV infection • Patients undergoing cancer chemotherapy, corticosteroid, antimetabolite or biologic immunomodulator therapy.




Reference: Online course https://www.cdc.gov/vaccines/pubs/pinkbook/downloads/tetanus.pdf

questions.text: Select the Zika virus's vector.
questions.solution:
Zika virus is transmitted primarily by the Aedes aegypti and Aedes albopictus mosquito species, commonly known as the yellow fever mosquito and Asian tiger mosquito, respectively. These species are known to be primary vectors for Zika, meaning they can acquire the virus by feeding on an infected individual, and then transmit it to other individuals by biting. Additionally, Zika can be transmitted by sexual contact with an infected individual, through transfusion of contaminated blood, and from an infected mother to her fetus during pregnancy. Finally, laboratory-acquired Zika virus infections have been reported.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 660.

questions.text:
Select the reason for a patient having fever for the last 3 days. His peripheral blood smear is stained with Geimsa shows the following. 

1. P. Falciparum
2. P. Vivax
3. P. Malaria
4. P. Ovale
questions.solution: The picture shows the ring form of a Plasmodium falciparum (P. falciparum) parasite, which is the cause of the most lethal form of human malaria. This ring form is found within the red blood cells (RBCs) of an infected individual and is the early stage of the parasite's life cycle known as the trophozoite stage. Multiple ring forms can be seen within a single RBC, indicating a high level of infectiousness. The ring form is responsible for the destruction of blood cells, which can lead to severe symptoms in the infected individual.

questions.text: Mention the fundamentals of the given test for HBV
questions.solution:
The immunochromatographic test for Hepatitis B Virus (HBV) is a diagnostic technique that utilizes a specialized cassette strip to detect the presence of three major antigens (HBsAg, HBAg and HBeAg) associated with HBV. The cassette contains a sample application pad, a conjugate pad, a nitrocellulose membrane, and a visible readout. The sample is first applied to the application pad and then transferred to the conjugate pad, which contains colored particles such as blue latex beads that are specifically bound to antibodies against the HBV antigens. When the sample is added to the conjugate pad, any HBV antigens present in the sample will bind to the antibodies in the conjugate pad, forming a visible cluster of colored particles. The sample is then transferred to the nitrocellulose membrane where the binded antigen-antibody complexes are able to migrate along the membrane. The membrane is then read visually. If a visible readout of the colored clusters appears then the test is considered positive and the patient is diagnosed as HBV positive.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 547.

questions.text: Pick the causative organism where a 12 years old boy gets vomiting within 3 hours of food consumption at a party.
questions.solution:
Staphylococcal food poisoning is a type of food poisoning caused by Staphylococcal enterotoxin, which is a heat and acid stable superantigen. It is a preformed toxin, meaning that its effects are felt within a short period of time (1-6 hours). Toxin is vagomimetic hence causes vomiting. There are 12 known serotypes of Staphylococcal enterotoxin, which are A-E, G-I, R-T and V, with serotype A being the most common cause of food poisoning. Contaminated food items such as dairy, bakery items, custards, salads, and processed meats are at high risk for contamination. Food handlers are the most common source of this contamination.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 204.

questions.text: Pick the suggestive method to use on a brother of a 5 years old boy who had a sore throat for the last two days. He has a greyish-white pseudomembrane around his tonsils and diphtheria is suspected. The brother got the last booster 22 months back.
questions.solution:
All contacts of a diphtheria patient irrespective of whether they received their primary immunization or booster dose, Prophylaxis with oral erythromycin is required. Those whose primary course or booster dose was received more than two years ago should only receive a booster dose of diphtheria toxoid. Non-immunized close contacts should receive prophylactic penicillin or erythromycin and also receive 1000-2000 units of diphtheria antitoxin as well as active immunization against diphtheria. All contacts should be placed under medical surveillance and should be examined daily for at least a week after being exposed, and the bacteriological surveillance of those close contacts should be continued for several weeks doing weekly swabbing.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 245.

questions.text: What is the cause for the Antiseptic property of bleaching powder?
questions.solution:
• Bleaching powder, also known as calcium hypochlorite (CaOCi2) is produced when chlorine is passed through calcium chloride. Upon dissolving in water, it reacts with the water to form hypochlorous acid (HOCI) and hypochlorite ions (OCI-).
  • Both are potent oxidizing agents and act as disinfectants - However, it is the hypochlorous acid(HOCl) that is the most potent form of disinfectant(70-80 times more effective than hypochlorite ion) because the neutral hypochlorous acid can better penetrate cell walls of pathogenic microorganisms than the negatively charged hypochlorite ion. 
Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 577.

questions.text: Pick the reason for donovanosis.
questions.solution:
Donovanosis (also known as Granuloma Inguinale) is a genital ulcer disease, caused by the bacteria known as Klebsiella (Calymmatobacterium) granulomatis. It is a rare but serious infection that is mainly spread through sexual contact. It is believed to be more common in tropical and subtropical regions. Those infected may present with painless, hypertrophic ulcers which have raised margins. A definitive diagnosis of donovanosis can be made of the presence of a “Donovan Body” in a Giemsa stain. This is a rounded coccobacilli, resembling a “safety-pin” appearance within cystic spaces in large mononuclear cells. The infection is treated with antibiotics, such as tetracycline or doxycycline. Early diagnosis and treatment can prevent further spread of the infection.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 404.

questions.text: Select the one which doesn't cause Urethritis in males.
questions.solution:
Haemophilus ducreyi is a gram-negative bacterium that causes a sexually transmitted infection known as soft chancre or chancroid. The infection is characterized by multiple, painful, non-indurated (not hard) irregular ulcers on the genital area. It is usually accompanied with painful regional lymphadenopathy (swollen lymph nodes, usually on one side). The ulcers can be quite painful and can lead to secondary infections if left untreated.
Treatment involves antibiotics, and those individuals who have been infected with this bacteria should be tested for other STIs. It is a common cause of urinary tract infections (UTIs) in females and has been associated with post-surgical infections in the urethra. However, it does not cause urethritis in males. This is because the male urethra is much longer than the female, making it difficult for Haemophilus ducreyi to traverse and cause infections. In addition, the acidic environment of the male urethra helps to inhibit bacterial growth. Therefore, Haemophilus ducreyi does not typically cause urethritis in males

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 337.

questions.text: Choose the one caused due to traumatic inoculation.
questions.solution:
Sporothrix schenckii is a thermally dimorphic fungi known to cause a chronic fungal infection called sporotrichosis. It is most commonly found in gardeners through infection with a rose prick, therefore called rose gardener's disease. The incubation period for this infection is usually between 1-3 weeks. A sample of the fungus can be examined under a microscope and will show an asteriod body when observed with a KOH/HE solution, or cigar-shaped bodies on tissue sections. Immunohistochemical staining can show a Splendore-Hoppli phenomenon which is an immune complex deposition around the organism. In addition, the mycelial form of the fungi shows a 'flowerlike pattern.' To test for this infection, skin tests involving Sporotrichin or peptido-rhamno-mannan antigen can be used. It spreads through lymphatic route this lesions are spaced and linear in distribution, this pattern is known as Sporotrichoid pattern. 

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 606.

questions.text: Pick the one which is incorrect about J.E.
questions.solution:
Japanese encephalitis (JE) is an infectious disease caused by the Japanese encephalitis virus which is primarily transmitted through the bites of Culex mosquitoes. These mosquitoes feed on infected birds, mammals and pigs, acting as the reservoirs for the virus. Humans are not reservoirs because they are dead-end or dead-cycle hosts for JE virus. This means that when a human is bitten by an infected mosquito, the virus will not reproduce in his/her body and can not be spread directly to other humans. Japanese encephalitis is also transmitted indirectly through contaminated food and water products, especially pork and poultry, due to the virus's presence in the salivary glands of pigs and birds. Thus, the indirect transmission of the virus is through the ingestion of insufficiently cooked contaminated animal products.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 527.

choices.text: No vaccine needed as exposure has already occurred

questions.text: Select the suggestive measure to be given to a 12 years old close friend who is in fear of contracting d/s from her friend who has been diagnosed with meningococcal meningitis.
questions.solution:
Meningococcal vaccine protects against four antigens related to four specific serotypes, A, C, Y, and W135. While vaccines for serotype B are still being evaluated, two types of vaccines are in use: capsular polysaccaride vaccines and conjugate vaccines. Only polysaccaride vaccines are licensed for use in our country, which come in bivalent (A+C) and tetravalent (A+C+Y+W135) forms. Each dose of the vaccine contains 50 Mg of the antigen and is given as a 0.5 ml injection subcutaneously in the deltoid region to those over two years old. The duration of immunity following the vaccine is 1-3 years. Singled dose of polysaccharide meningococcal vaccine would be prescribed in this case.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 233.

questions.text: Vaccination for which of the following diseases are not included in Indradhanush mission?
questions.solution: Reference-Ghai Essential Pediatrics 9th Edition Page no 185

questions.text: Mention the diagnosis of an HIV positive patient with a CD4 count of 300 cells/cumm presents with mucosal lesions in the mouth as shown in the figure. On microscopy, budding yeasts and pseudohyphae are seen.
questions.solution:
The given image is of Oral Thrush(Candidiasis) which can be scrapped off and microscopy showing pseudohyphae confirms the diagnosis. HIV patients are at an increased risk of developing Candidiasis due to lower levels of CD4+ cells and/or antiretroviral therapy (ARV) treatments, which can lead to an overgrowth of the Candida fungus. The fungi can either cause infection when it enters through openings in the skin, or due to a weakened immune system, penetrate through mucosal surfaces and enter the bloodstream.

 

Signs of Candidiasis in HIV patients: The most common signs of Candidiasis in HIV patients are oral thrush (discolored patches in the mouth), as well as skin infections such as red/irritated rashes and itchy skin. In addition, HIV patients can experience persistent coughs, mucus production, and chest discomfort. Candidiasis can also lead to more severe issues such as meningitis and esophagitis.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 616.

questions.text: Name the strain of influenza which got declared as pandemic in 2009.
questions.solution:
The H1N1 strain of influenza, also known as swine flu, was declared a pandemic by the World Health Organization (WHO) in June 2009. The declaration was made after the virus had spread rapidly around the world and began to cause significant levels of illness and death in many countries. The decision to declare it a pandemic was based on the fact that the virus had caused significant disruption in many countries and had been transmitted easily between people and between countries.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 509.

questions.text: Pick the one which helps in bacterial adhesion.
questions.solution:
Fimbriae are thin projections on the surface of bacterial cells that are involved in bacterial adhesion. They are important in the infectious process, allowing bacteria to attach to surfaces and spread to new locations. Fimbriae are made of proteins and act like short, thin, flexible fingers that extend outward from the cell membrane. These fingers are coated in carbohydrates, lipids, and other molecules that recognize and bind to a specific receptor on the surface of the target cell, allowing the bacteria to attach. Once attached, the bacteria will grow and reproduce.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 20.

questions.text: Name the category A bioterrorism agent amongst the following.
questions.solution:
Category A bioterrorism agents are biological agents that have the potential to cause mass casualties and panic.
Category A bioterrorism agents include

  • Anthrax (Bacillus anthracis)
  • Botulism (Clostridium botulinum toxin)
  • Plague (Yersinia pestis)
  • Smallpox (variola major)
  • Tularemia (Francisella tularensis)
  • Viral hemorrhagic fevers (filoviruses [e.g., Ebola, Marburg] and arenaviruses [e.g., Lassa, Machupo])
Category B- Minority priority agents, Moderately well disseminated, Moderate morbidity and low mortality. Eg- Coxiella burnetti, Burkholderia mallei, Burkholderia psedomallei, Ricin toxin, Cryptosporidum parvum, Salmonella typhi, Chlamydia psittaci. Category C- Low priority agents, could be engineered for mass dissemination, Readily available, Easy to produce, Potentially high morbidity and mortality. Eg- Emergent viruses: Nipah and Hantavirus, corona, H1N1, Mycobacterium tuberculosis.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 662.

questions.text: Pick the one which produces superantigens.
questions.solution:
Superantigens are antigens that can directly activate T cells without being processed by APCs, unlike other antigens which require processing. Superantigens bind to the variable region of the T-cell receptor and activate many T cells at once, causing a massive release of cytokines. This polyclonal B cell activation can lead to increased secretion of non-specific antibodies (hypergammaglobulinemia). Streptococcal pyrogenic exotoxin (SPE) is a superantigen responsible for streptococcal infections like scarlet fever, necrotising fascitis and toxic shock syndrome. It is classified into three antigenic types: SPE A, B, and C, where SPE A and C are superantigens. The Dick test is used to detect exposure to SPE and determine susceptibility to scarlet fever.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 93.

questions.text: Mention the class of antibody shown in the immunoglobulin structure.
questions.solution:
Immunoglobulin A (IgA) is a type of antibody found in the secretions of the body such as saliva, tears, respiratory and intestinal mucosal secretions. IgA is a dimer, consisting of two monomers joined together by a J-chain. There are two subclasses of IgA, IgA1, found predominately in serum, and IgA2, found predominantly in the body secretions. Due to its secretory component, IgA is effective at mediating local or mucosal immunity, meaning it can protect against infection on the mucosal surface like in the digestive or respiratory system. IgA is the most abundant antibody found in the human body and is therefore important in protecting against infections.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 99.

questions.text: Name the organism which causes reactivation d/s within 1-4 months after renal transplant surgery.
questions.solution:
Cytomegalovirus (CMV) is a virus from the herpesvirus family that is associated with immunosuppression in people with HIV/AIDS and organ transplant recipients. CMV can cause cytopathic effects such as cytomegaly and nucleomegaly, as well as the formation of large intranuclear inclusions, which have an Owl’s eye appearance (Cowdry type A inclusion). These inclusions stain positively for PAS and GMS. CMV can be congenitally transmitted through the placenta or perinatally through cervical or vaginal secretions.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 479.

questions.text: A child develops septic shock following meningitis. On examination the child has a petechiae rash as shown in the figure. Which of the following is a gram negative diplococcus that can be the likely etiology?
questions.solution:
Neisseria meningitidis is a type of bacteria that is responsible for many cases of meningitis and other serious infections. The bacteria is a capsulated, intracellular gram-negative diplococci, meaning that under a microscope it appears as two lenses in a half-moon shape and it is classified into thirteen different serogroups based on the capsular polysaccharide that coats the organism.
Humans are the only natural host for infection by this bacteria. Transmission is through inhalation of droplets.
Disease caused by Neisseria meningitidis can be diagnosed through Gram staining, culturing on selective media, serological testing, and molecular testing such as multiplex PCR.
Treatment of disease caused by Neisseria meningitidis can be done with antibiotics such as ceftriaxone and cefotaxime or penicillin, chemoprophylaxis with rifampicin and ciprotioxacin, and vaccine prophylaxis such as a polysaccharide vaccines. Pseudomonas aeruginosa and Escherichia coli are both gram-negative bacilli and Streptococcus pneumonia is a gram-positive diplococci.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 232.

questions.text: As shown in the figure mention the common soil transmitted Helminth infection in India which is characterized by eggs in stool.
questions.solution: Trichuris trichiura, commonly known as whipworm, is a large intestinal nematode. This is a type of parasitic roundworm that lives in the human small intestine. The eggs of this species are barrel-shaped, measuring 50 µm long and 25 µm wide in the middle, and contain a mucous plug at each pole. These eggs of Trichuris trichiura are bile-stained and float in a saturated salt solution. The infective form of Trichuris trichiura is the embryonated egg, which contains a rhabditiform larvae. These larvae are capable of reinfecting their hosts after the egg is ingested.

questions.text: Which amongst the following is the widening of the  cartilaginous part of the external auditory canal?
questions.solution:
Meatoplasty is a surgical procedure in which a small portion of the conchal cartilage, known as the meatus, is removed to widen the cavity. This procedure helps to ensure the healthy growth of epithelial tissue in the mastoid cavity and is commonly combined with radical and modified radical mastoidectomies in order to provide access for further inspection and cleaning. It can also be done as a standalone procedure to improve the appearance of sagging outer ears in older individuals.

Reference : P L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck surgery , 7th Edition- page 455

questions.text: What is the most likely diagnosis in a child who presented with fever and dysphagia with the following visualization.
questions.solution:
Peritonsillar Abscess is a common condition affecting the area around the tonsils. It occurs when bacteria or other infectious organisms, mostly GABHS, get trapped in the space between the tonsil and its covering membrane. It is frequently accompanied by fever, sore throat, difficulty swallowing, and an asymmetric tonsillar bulge with displacement of the uvula away from the affected side. This clinical picture is highly diagnostic of Peritonsillar Abscess, which is treated with antibiotics and, in some cases, surgical drainage.

Reference : P L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck surgery , 7th Edition- page 299

questions.text: Select the medium for E.Coli 0157:H7.
questions.solution:
Sorbitol MacConkey agar is a selective and differential agar used to identify bacteria that can ferment the sugar sorbitol. It is used specifically to identify and differentiate E. coli O157:H7 from other E. coli strains. It is an exclusive medium as it only allows the growth of E. coli O157:H7 colonies and will not support the growth of other coliform bacteria. It is a differentiating medium too, as the colonies of E. coli O157:H7 produce a yellow-green color with a metallic sheen on the agar, while other coliforms produce pink to red colonies.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 286.

questions.text: Which one is not a part of ASEPSIS wound grading
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Induration

The ASEPSIS wound scoring method is an acronym for Additional treatment, Serous discharge, Erythema, Purulent exudate, Separation of deep tissues, Isolation of bacteria, and Stay as inpatient prolonged over 14 days.
This is a scoring system for the severity of wound infection, which are particularly useful in surveillance and research.


Fig: ASEPSIS wound scoring

Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 48.

questions.text: In otherwise healthy 40 yr old man Management of a RCC less than 4 cm in size?
questions.solution:
Renal cell carcinoma staging is based on the size, position and lymph node involvement of a tumor.

  • Stage I indicates a tumor that is less than 7 cm in the largest dimension and localized to the kidney.
  • Stage II is larger than 7 cm and localized to the kidney.
  • Stage III is when the tumor has extended beyond the Gerota's fascia, or regional lymph nodes are involved.
  • Partial nephrectomy is indicated for patients with T1 tumors (less than 7 cm confined to the kidney, stage I).
  • Classic radical nephrectomy involves removing the entire kidney, perineal fat, adrenal gland and regional lymph nodes. However, when the tumor is smaller than 5 cm and located at the inferior pole, the adrenal gland can be preserved, as well as the regional lymph node dissection in cases of clinically positive nodes detected on CT.
Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 1482.

choices.text: USG monitoring till size of the aneurysm reaches 70 mm

questions.text: Select the correct management procedure of a patient with mild abdominal pain and an abdominal aortic aneurysm
questions.solution:
Abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) is the most common type of large vessel aneurysm, found in 2% of the population. It usually remains asymptomatic, but may cause mild symptoms like back pain and abdominal discomfort.
However, rupture of an aneurysm produces severe pain in the back and abdomen, in addition to hypotension. The annual risk of rupture is low (1% or less) for aneurysms that are smaller than 55 mm in diameter, but increases significantly (up to 25%) for aneurysms with a diameter of 70 mm or more. Regular ultrasound assessments are indicated for asymptomatic aneurysms smaller than 55 mm in diameter, and repair of the aneurysm should be considered if the diameter is greater than 55 mm.

Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 1017.

questions.text: Name the vessel involved in cramping gluteal pain of a 30 years old mom after walking 500 m.
questions.solution:
Claudication pain is a type of cramping pain that is felt after walking or exercising.
  • It is caused by a decrease in the blood supply to the muscles due to arterial insufficiency.
  • Claudication pain typically affects the muscle group one anatomical level below the area suffering from arterial insufficiency.
  • For instance, if claudication pain is felt in the calf, the likely cause is an issue with the superficial femoral artery, which is the most common artery affected in 70% of cases. In 30% of cases, aorto-iliac disease is the cause of the claudication pain, and this can also be associated with sexual impotence. This combination of claudication pain and impotence is referred to as Leriche's syndrome.
  • Claudication pain is a type of cramping pain that is felt after walking or exercising.
  • It is caused by a decrease in the blood supply to the muscles due to arterial insufficiency. Claudication pain typically affects the muscle group one anatomical level below the area suffering from arterial insufficiency.
  • For instance, if claudication pain is felt in the calf, the likely cause is an issue with the superficial femoral artery, which is the most common artery affected in 70% of cases. In 30% of cases, aorto-iliac disease is the cause of the claudication pain, and this can also be associated with sexual impotence. This combination of claudication pain and impotence is referred to as Leriche's syndrome.

Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 998.

questions.text: As shown in the barium image, mention the diagnosis on a patient with Halitosis and swelling in the lateral aspect of the neck which on pressing gives rise to a regurgitant air sound.
questions.solution:
Patient presented with halitosis and swelling over lateral aspect of neck, barium swallow suggested out pouching over cricopharyngeal region suggestive of zenker’s diverticulum

A particular kind of diverticulum called Zenker's diverticulum forms in the hypopharynx, usually in the space between the inferior pharyngeal constrictor muscle and the cricopharyngeus (CP) muscle. It is a false diverticulum since it only affects the mucosa and submucosal layers and not the muscle layer.

Reference : P L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck surgery , 7th Edition- page 310

questions.text: Mention the diagnosis of the following Barium X-ray.
questions.solution:
Correct option is 2. CA esophagus
 
  • The barium swallow has shown an irregular filling defect and narrowing with shouldered margins which may indicate the presence of either squamous cell carcinoma in the upper two-thirds of the esophagus, or adenocarcinoma in the lower third.
  • A further upper GI endoscopy and biopsy should be performed to confirm the diagnosis. If found to be suitable for potentially curative therapies, staging investigations should be done to ensure that the cancer has not spread to other parts of the body (CT scan).
  • If the cancer is localized, further staging tests should be performed to assess the loco-regional stage (endoscopic ultrasonography, endoscopic ultrasound +/- laparoscopy). These tests will allow for appropriate treatment planning and management of the cancer.
  • In Achalasia cardia- Bird's beak deformity is seen. 
Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 1136.

questions.text: A 20 years old boy following an RTA presented with respiratory distress and hypotension. He has subcutaneous emphysema and no air entry on the right side. Choose the next best step in management of this patient:
questions.solution:
The next best step in management should be Needle decompression/ thoracostomy @ 5th ICS through the triangle of safety. Previously it was done @2nd ICS at mid-clavicular line.

Management of spontaneous pneumothorax involves a two-step process:
  1. Emptying the air from the chest cavity: This is accomplished by inserting a large bore needle (usually 16 or 18 gauge) into the 5th intercostal space in the midaxillary line (point above the armpit). The patient will usually be in a sitting position and the needle is attached to a syringe or connected to a sterile drainage system. The needle should be inserted slowly and gently with steady pressure to allow for controlled drainage.
  2. Preventing further air from entering the chest cavity: Once the air has been emptied from the chest cavity, it is important to close off the opening in the chest wall to prevent more air from entering. This can be accomplished with a small steel clamp or a suture. The patient will then be monitored for a few days to ensure the pneumothorax has fully resolved.
Definitive management of Tension Pneumothorax is Tube thoracostomy (ICD insertion) @ 5th ICS in the mid-axillary line through triangle of safety.



Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th edition, Page no 374.
Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2200.

questions.text: Pick the Hinchey's stage for a patient with peritonitis and during surgery diverticular perforation is seen with purulent contamination.
questions.solution:
Correct option is 3. 3.

Hinchey classification is a system used to classify the severity of patients with peritonitis.
Peritonitis is an inflammation of the peritoneum, a membrane that lines the inner wall of the abdomen and covers the abdominal organs.

The Hinchey classification is divided into four stages (I-IV), with each stage representing a varying degree of peritonitis severity.
  • Stage I: This stage is the least severe and includes patients with localized peritonitis and mild abdominal pain. Symptoms may also include tenderness, rebound tenderness and guarding.
  • Stage II: This stage includes patients with diffuse peritonitis and more severe abdominal pain. In addition, there may be systemic signs of infection such as fever and tachycardia.
  • Stage III: This stage includes patients with diffuse peritonitis and more severe systemic signs of infection, such as hypotension and hypothermia. Patients may also have abdominal distension, widespread ileus (restricted peristalsis of the intestine), and abscesses.
  • Stage IV: This is the most severe stage characterized by  generalized fecal peritonitis, and includes patients with peritonitis-related organ failure. Organs may include the heart, lungs, kidneys and/or liver. In addition, these patients may have multi-organ dysfunction, sepsis, and require a high level of supportive care.


Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 1368.

choices.text: 50% reduction in PTH within 10 mins of gland removal
50% reduction in PTH within 5 mins of gland removal
25% reduction in PTH within 10 mins of gland removal
25% reduction in PTH within 5 mins of gland removal

questions.text: How is removal of the correct gland after surgery confirmed in parathyroid adenoma?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) 50% reduction in PTH within 10 mins of gland removal

The Miami Criteria are used to assess the effectiveness of removing a single adenoma in a patient with hyperparathyroidism.

  • The criteria measure the drop in the circulating plasma PTH (parathyroid hormone) level 10 minutes after resection.
  • A drop in the PTH level to less than half its maximum preoperative levels and to the normal range indicates successful resection and single-gland disease.
  • If the drop in PTH is not detected or is insufficient, multiple gland disease is suspected and further treatment or exploration may be necessary. The half life of PTH is 3-5 minutes, allowing for a significant drop to be detected in the plasma following resection of a single adenoma.

Fig: Miami criteria for intraoperative parathyroid hormone (PTH) measurement. Drop of PTH into the normal range and less than half the maximum value at 10 minutes postresection.

Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 880.

questions.text: A 44 year old man presented to OPD with complaints of dysphagia to both solid and liquids. Esophageal manometry was performed and it showed an abnormally elevated lower esophageal pressure of > 450 mm along with premature contractions with > 20% of swallows? What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 3. Type 3 achalasia

Achalasia is a type of esophageal motility disorder that is characterized by a failure of the lower esophageal sphincter (LES) to relax, resulting in difficulty swallowing.

* According to Chicago classification: 

Type I achalasia (classic)
Median IRP >15 mm Hg, 100% failed peristalsis (DCI <100 mm Hg-s-cm); premature contractions with DCI <450 mm Hg-s•cm satisfy criteria for failed peristalsis

Type Il achalasia (with esophageal compression) -Median IRP >15 mm Hg; 100% failed peristalsis, panesophageal pressurization with ≥20% of swallows

Type Ill achalasia (spastic achalasia) - Median IRP >15 mm Hg; no normal peristalsis, spastic contractions with DCI >450 mm Hg-s•cm with ≥20% of swallows

Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 1122.
