questions.text: With Maize as her staple diet, What deficiency does a patient have when she also has diarrhea and lesions on her neck?
questions.solution:
Diarrhea, dermatitis (lesions on the neck), and a maize-rich diet - all point towards Niacin deficiency (option 1) also known as Pellagra.
It is caused by a lack of dietary niacin or its precursor, the amino acid tryptophan. A maize (corn) diet is one possible cause of pellagra, due to its low tryptophan content and hence, low conversion to niacin in the body causing niacin deficiency and symptoms of Pellagra. 




Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 31st Edition, Page no 528.

questions.text: What is the replacement required in place of amino acid to increase UV immersion of protein at 280 nm wavelength?
questions.solution:
Proteins absorb light at specific wavelengths, with certain amino acids responsible for the absorbance. Tyrosine and tryptophan contain aromatic rings, which cause a peak of absorbance at 280nm. By measuring how much light is absorbed at 280nm, we can estimate protein concentration. This is referred to as UV absorbance at 280nm, and is a common laboratory technique for measuring protein concentration.



Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 32nd Edition, Page no 21.

questions.text: Which amino acid is Nitric oxide (NO) derived from
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) L-arginine
 
  • In humans, NO is synthesized from the amino acid arginine with the aid of several different enzymes, including the enzyme nitric oxide synthase (NOS).
  • NOS catalyzes the formation of NO from arginine and oxygen by transferring a terminal guanidino nitrogen to form L-citrulline. This reaction is coupled to the hydrolysis of NADPH and the overall reaction involves five steps known as the nitric oxide synthase (NOS) pathway.
  • First, arginine is converted to N-hydroxy arginine, followed by a series of electron transfer reactions within the NOS enzyme. Then, the N-hydroxyarginine is converted to citrulline, and nitric oxide is released. Finally, the citrulline is converted back to arginine, completing the cycle. Together, these steps form the nitric oxide synthesizing reaction from arginine in humans.
Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 83.

questions.text: What forms the genetic basis of synthesis of Apolipoprotein B48?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) RNA editing
 

  • Apolipoprotein B-48 (apoB-48) is a remnant of RNA editing, which is a post-transcriptional process of altering the primary sequence of an RNA molecule after it is transcribed from a gene in the genome.
  • RNA editing can involve the addition, removal, or substitution of specific nucleotides in an RNA molecule. This process helps to diversify the proteins encoded by different genes and has been identified in a variety of organisms, including humans.
  • ApoB-48 is a truncated form of ApoB-100, the primary apolipoprotein found in chylomicrons, which are particles produced by the small intestine and involved in the absorption of dietary fats and cholesterol.
  • ApoB-48 is produced through a process of somatic (or “adult”) RNA editing and is found in blood plasma and VLDL (very low-density lipoprotein) particles. It has been shown to play a role in the metabolism of cholesterol, chylomicron remnant uptake, and bile acid homeostasis.

Reference: Harrison’s Principals of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page No 698.

questions.text: Which among the following options given below have maximum water absorption ?
questions.solution:
Among the given options, pectin has the maximum water absorption capacity.

Explanation:

• Pectin: A highly hydrophilic polysaccharide that forms gels by binding large amounts of water. It has the greatest water-holding capacity among the options.

• Mucilage: Also absorbs water well but generally not as much as pectin.

• Hemicellulose: Can retain some water but is less hydrophilic than pectin.

• Lignin: Has minimal water absorption as it is a highly hydrophobic and rigid polymer.

.

Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 31st Edition, Page no 154.

questions.text: Vitamin b12 is richest in
questions.solution:
Vitamin B12 belongs to the B family of vitamins. It helps to regulate the nervous system and plays a major role in the synthesis of DNA and the production of red blood cells. It also helps to convert food into energy.

 

The most common sources of Vitamin B12 are animal-based foods such as eggs, yogurt, milk, fish, and meat products. Vegans or vegetarians may need to consume fortified foods or take a supplemental to obtain the needed quantities. Supplements are sometimes derived from microorganisms, so vegans can look for these. However, not all fortified foods are vegan, so it is important to check the label. Vitamin B12 can also be taken as an injection or topical cream.

Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 31st Edition, Page no 536.

questions.text: Mention the enzyme which gets activated when there is decrease in insulin: glucagon ratio:
questions.solution:
• Insulin and glucagon are both hormones responsible for maintaining glucose (sugar) levels in the blood.
  • Their ratio helps regulate the activity of several enzymes, which are proteins that speed up chemical reactions in the body.
  • An increase in the insulin-to-glucagon ratio reduces the activity of hormone-sensitive lipase, an enzyme responsible for breaking down fat stored in the body. In contrast, an increase in the glucagon-to-insulin ratio activates the enzyme, increasing the breakdown of stored fat.
The ratio also regulates enzymes involved in the synthesis of fatty acids, the breakdown of glycogen, and the breakdown and synthesis of glucose in the liver by there action on Glucose 6 phosphatase. In this way, the insulin-to-glucagon ratio controls many of the metabolic pathways within the body.

Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 31st Edition, Page no 144.

questions.text: Proteoglycan present in Glomerular basement membrane is:
questions.solution:
The glomerular capillary membrane makes the filtration barrier that allows for the passage of certain substances from the blood into the glomerular filtrate. This membrane consists of three major layers: capillary endothelium, capillary basement membrane, and layer of epithelial cells surrounding the outer surface of the capillary basement membrane (podocytes). The capillary endothelium layer is freely permeable to everything in the blood except for red blood cells and platelets, up to a size of 4 nm in diameter. The capillary basement membrane contains proteins, such as laminin, type VI collagen, nidogen, and heparan sulfate proteoglycan (HSPG). These proteins form a meshwork which effectively prevents filtration of plasma proteins. The layer of podocytes surround the capillary basement membrane and have long foot-like processes with gaps in-between called slit pores, which are 25 nm wide. It is through these slit pores that the glomerular filtrate moves. The total area of glomerular capillary endothelium across which filtration occurs in humans is approximately 0.8m. This membrane is selective in how it permits materials through, allowing related to their size, charge, and other properties.



Reference :Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry 31st edition Page no 1474

questions.text: What vitamin is lacking if patient presents with the following?
questions.solution:
The image shows Casal necklace seen in Niacin deficieny. Vitamin B3 (also known as niacin or nicotinic acid) is an essential nutrient involved in hundreds of biochemical reactions in the body. Deficiency of this vitamin can lead to pellagra, a condition characterized by skin lesions, gastrointestinal disturbances, and mental disturbances. Symptoms of vitamin B3 deficiency can include inflamed and scaly skin in sun-exposed areas (pellagra rash), sore or inflamed tongue and mouth, mental confusion, diarrhea, headaches, anorexia and fatigue. Other possible signs of deficiency include poor circulation, depression, irritability, and a weakened immune system. If left untreated, severe deficiency can lead to seizures, coma, or even death.

Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 31st Edition, Page no 534.

questions.text: Mention the deficiency when a 45-year-old has paresthesia and Hb=6.8g/dL. Peripheral smear shows macrocytes and neutrophils with hypersegmented nuclei. Endoscopy reveals atrophic gastritis.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Vit. B12 deficiency

  • Pernicious anemia (PA) is an autoimmune macrocytic anemia caused by a vitamin B12 deficiency due to a lack of intrinsic factor which is an important factor for the absorption of B12 in the small intestine.
  • Vitamin B12 deficiency can lead to neurological symptoms such as paresthesia, and a decreased Hemoglobin (Hb) value of 6gm% is a sign of anemia.
  • Characteristic features seen on a peripheral smear that occurs due to megaloblastic anemia can include macrocytes, and neutrophils with hyper segmented nuclei.
  • Endoscopy findings can reveal atrophy of gastric mucosa, which can result in decreased absorption of vitamin B12 due to a lack of intrinsic factor, and therefore lead to its deficiency.


Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 652.

questions.text: Identify the lipid with deficiency in a preterm baby having respiratory distress syndrome?
questions.solution:
Respiratory Distress Syndrome (RDS) in preterm babies is caused by a deficiency of surfactant, a complex mixture of phospholipids mainly dipalmitoyphosphatidyIcholine, proteins, neutral lipids and cholesterol. Cardiolipin (Culcutta antigens) is a phospholipid which is a component of the inner mitochondrial membrane and plays an important role in mitochondrial enzyme metabolism. Sphingomyelin are also phosphosphingolipids which are found in increased concentrations in nervous tissues, red blood cells and lens of the eyes. The lack of or insufficient surfactant production in the respiratory system of preterm babies is responsible for the alveolar collapse and leads to the onset of RDS.


Reference- Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology Edition 26 th Page no 620

questions.text: Name the active drug with inhibition of DNA to RNA transcription
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) Rifampicin
 
  • Rifampicin binds to the beta subunit of the DNA- dependent RNA polymerase and inhibits RNA synthesis in the bacteria.
  • It is bactericidal. In therapeutic concentrations, rifampicin cannot bind human RNA polymerase and it, therefore, selectively destroys the bacteria.
  • Moreover, it reaches the cavities, caseous material and penetrates macrophages.
Other options: -
  • Novobiocin and Ciprofloxacin are DNA Gyrase inhibitors
  • Nitrofurantoin inhibits DNA and RNA synthesis.
Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 818.

questions.text: Name the cell kind, baby with respiratory distress syndrome would lack with
questions.solution:
Alveolar capillary endothelial cells are part of the capillary wall that lines the inner surface of the vasculature. These cells help to maintain hemostasis by preventing the coagulation of the blood and ensuring that all blood flows smoothly through the capillaries. Type I alveolar cells form part of the air-blood barrier, and they are involved in the process of gas exchange between the alveoli and the blood. Type 2 cells contain secretory organelles known as lamellar bodies, which are responsible for the release of pulmonary surfactant. Alveolar macrophages are a type of immune cells that are responsible for clearing the air space. They can remove any infectious, toxic, or allergic particles, as well as secreting interleukin 4 and 10 to control any risk of uncontrolled inflammation.

Thus, a lack of Type 2 alveolar cells would lead to Respiratory Distress Syndrome in a newborn baby. 

 

Reference- Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology Edition 26 th Page no 611

questions.text: Name the reflex in which there is inhibition of gastric emptying when there is acid and hypertonic solution in the duodenum.
questions.solution:
Enterogastric reflex is a reflex pathway triggered by certain stimuli in the small intestine and activates nerve cells in the myenteric plexus, causing inhibitory nerve impulses to the stomach. These impulses cause the stomach to slow or even stop the emptying of food into the small intestine. The purpose of enterogastric reflex is to allow the body more time to digest an incoming meal and to ensure necessary nutrients are absorbed. This can prevent the symptoms of a substandard nutrient intake, such as malnutrition or malabsorption.



Reference- Guyton and Hall Textbook of Medical Physiology, 13th Edition Page no 811,812

questions.text: Slow conduction of the motor and sensory pathway in multiple sclerosis is due to which of the following reasons?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Loss of myelin sheath

  • Multiple Sclerosis (MS) is an autoimmune disorder of the central nervous system (CNS) caused by chronic inflammation and resulting in demyelination, gliosis (plaques or scarring) and neuronal loss.
  • The disease can progress in a relapsing or progressive manner.
  • The myelin sheath, which facilitates nerve conduction, is affected, causing conduction block and hyperpolarization of the nerve axon. To compensate, the sodium channels redistribute, allowing for continuous propagation through the demyelinated section.
Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 1269.

questions.text: The Proteoglycan is located in the glomerular basement membrane. Select from the options the most appropriate one for the statement mentioned.
Which of the following clotting factor in a patient on warfarin therapy, would have decreased gamma carboxyglutamate residue?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Factor 2
 
  • Warfarin is an anticoagulant medication used to reduce the risk of stroke, thromboembolism, and other related events in people with certain medical conditions.
  • It works by inhibiting vitamin K-dependent clotting factors, including factor 2 (prothrombin), which is essential for the formation of fibrin, a protein required for clot formation.
  • Warfarin treatment both reduces the availability of factor 2 and weakens the fibrin bonds, leading to an decrease in the ability of the body to form a clot.
  • In addition, warfarin has been shown to slow the rate of thrombus formation, thus reducing the risk of stroke and other blood clot-related events.
  • Vitamin K-dependent clotting factors are 2,7,9,10.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 668.

questions.text: Water-hammer pulse is seen in:
questions.solution:
Water hammer pulse is a characteristic of aortic regurgitation (AR) which is a condition that occurs when the aortic valve does not close completely.

  • This allows for blood to leak backwards from the aorta into the left ventricle during diastole. This abnormality in the flow of blood is what causes the water hammer pulse in aortic regurgitation.
  • The pulse may be observed as a rapid alternating rise and fall of the arterial waveform in response to each heart beat. It has a snapping or palpable nature to it and is most often seen in the carotid artery.
  • It is typically accompanied by a loud radiated sound (“machinery murmur”) heard over the lower left sternal border during systole.
  • Water hammer pulse occurs due to a sudden and dramatic increase in diastolic blood pressure- caused by the regurgitated blood.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 1988.

questions.text: An aged woman around 65 has vascular injury in the inferior frontal gyrus. Which of the following systems given  below would be affected the most?
questions.solution:
The premotor area is located just anterior to the motor area, occupying parts of the superior, middle, and inferior frontal gyri. Areas 6 and 8 of Brodmann, and Areas 44 and 45 (the motor speech area of Broca) are part of the premotor area and are important for motor control and the execution of voluntary movement. Additionally, the frontal eye field - an area of the cortex involved in controlling eye movement - is also closely related to the premotor area.



Reference-:Guyton and Hall Textbook of Medical Physiology, 13th Edition Page no. 611

questions.text: In a motor bike accident, a boy was injured, CT brain shows the same lesion in posterior end of superior temporal gyrus. What is the most likely diagnosis ?
questions.solution:
Wernicke's aphasia is a type of language deficit that is characterized by impaired comprehension of spoken and written words and sentences and difficulty producing language, hence it causes fluent aphasia. It is caused by a lesion in the posterior part of the language network, commonly a vascular embolism to the inferior division of the middle cerebral artery.

 

Broca's aphasia is a type of language deficit characterized by difficulty in producing language. It is caused by a lesion in the inferior frontal convolution or surrounding anterior perisylvian and insular cortex, largely due to occlusion of the superior division of the MCA. Speech is nonfluent, labored, and interrupted by many word-finding pauses.

 

Conduction aphasia is a type of language deficit characterized by fluent but inaccurate language output with phonemic paraphasias, extreme difficulty in repetition, impaired naming, and impaired reading of words aloud. It is caused by a lesion in the temporoparietal or dorsal perisylvian region that interrupts the phonological loop connecting the Broca's area and the Wernicke's area.



 

Reference: Gray's Anatomy The Anatomical Basis Of Clinical Practice Edition 42 nd Page no 533
Guyton and Hall Textbook of Medical Physiology, 13th Edition Page no. 611

questions.text: The lab reports of a patient given below pH=7.2 HCO3- =10 mEq/L PCO2 = 35 mm Hg This exemplifies which of the following disorder
questions.solution:
Correct option is 3: Metabolic acidosis.
  • In this case: pH = 7.2 (Normal: 7.35-7.45, below 7.35 is considered acidic), blood is too acidic HCO3- (bicarbonate) = 10 mEq/L (Normal range: 22-26 mEq/L).
  • The bicarbonate level is also low, which is another sign of metabolic acidosis.
  • PaCO2 (partial pressure of carbon dioxide) = 35 mm Hg (normal range: 35-45 mm Hg), The PaCO2 is normal, which means that the respiratory system is not contributing to the acidosis.
Trick:- ROMS for pH and pCO2
Respiratory Opposite 
Metabolic Same

questions.text: Tachypnea and mental confusion was found in a man aged 55, with ph = 7.0 and blood glucose 350 mg/dl. Name the acid base from the following
questions.solution:
Correct option is 3: Metabolic acidosis

The given information points to metabolic acidosis based on the following factors:
  1. Tachypnea: Refers to rapid breathing and is a compensatory mechanism to eliminate excess CO2 (acid) from the body in response to acidosis.
  2. Mental confusion: Acidosis can lead to central nervous system (CNS) depression, resulting in symptoms like confusion.

pH 7.0 (Normal: 7.35-7.45) is low indicating acidosis. Blood glucose = 350 mg/dl: Elevated blood glucose levels can lead to diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA), which is a type of metabolic acidosis commonly seen in uncontrolled diabetes.

Trick:- ROMS for pH and pCO2
Respiratory Opposite 
Metabolic Same




Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 359-361.

choices.text: Normal person after waking up in morning cortical awakening response

questions.text: Select from the options, where there is elevated ACTH and cortisol levels in the morning in comparison the levels of those hormones in the evening in a human being
questions.solution:
• Corticotropin releasing hormone (CRH) is a hormone naturally produced by the hypothalamus in higher levels of CNS control. This hormone has the ability to stimulate the production of ACTH in the pituitary gland. ACTH is secreted from the pituitary in irregular bursts throughout the day, and the plasma cortisol level varies accordingly.
  • The circadian rhythm is controlled by the suprachiasmatic nucleus of the hypothalamus which causes the highest levels of ACTH secretion to occur before waking up in the morning and diminish late in the afternoon and early evening.
  • Stressors such as physical trauma, exercise, and mental stress can increase ACTH and cortisol secretion in response to the stressor.

Other options:-
 
  • Option 1: In Addison's disease, there is a deficiency of mineralocorticoids and glucocorticoids Cushing's syndrome is characterized by an overproduction of cortisol.
  • Option 2: In normal person after giving dexamethasone the ACTH will be supressed that will lead to decrease in cortisol level.
  • Option 4: Cushing's syndrome is characterized by an overproduction of cortisol. Excess ACTH secretion is the primary cause of Cushing's syndrome and is characterized by an increase of both ACTH and cortisol in the blood. But the diurnal variation won't be there.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2959-2962.
Guyton and Hall Textbook of Medical Physiology, 13th edition, page no 977, 979, 980.

questions.text:
What does it mean when it VA/Q is ∞
1. Partial pressure of alveolar gas is same as dead space
2. The pO2 of alveolar air is 159 mm Hg and PCO2 is 40 mm Hg
3. Partial pressure of O2 and CO2 are equal
4. No diffusion of O2 from alveoli to blood and CO2 from blood to alveolar gas
questions.solution:
VA/Q is a ratio used to describe the proportion of ventilation (V) to perfusion (Q) of air in the lungs. When no exchange of CO2 and O2 occurs, VA/Q is at infinity because there is no air moving between the two processes. In this case, the VA/Q ratio would be infinite because there is no exchange of gasses between the alveoli and pulmonary capillaries, causing infinite ventilation for every unit of perfusion (Q).

Statement 1 is also correct since if there is no perfusion then there is no gas exchange hence the partial pressure of the alveoli will be same as that of dead space.

This is a highly controversial question but option 4 seems the better answer.
 

Reference :Guyton and Hall Textbook of Medical Physiology, 13th Edition page no 525

choices.text: Bulging of tricuspid valve during the isovolumetric contraction phase

questions.text: JVP with C wave is due to
questions.solution:
The C wave of the jugular venous pulse (JVP) is created by the bulging of the tricuspid valve during ventricular systole, when the right ventricle contracts. As the right ventricle contracts, the tricuspid valve is forced open, allowing the blood to flow through the tricuspid valve into the right atrium. The increase in pressure in the right atrium causes the jugular vein to bulge and create the C wave of the JVP.

The jugular venous pulse (JVP) is observed to look different due to factors such as changes in the heart rate, respiratory rate, and intrathoracic pressure. Waves in the JVP include the a wave, c wave, v wave, and x and y descents. The a wave is caused by right atrial contraction, the c wave is related to the bulging of the tricuspid valve, the v wave is related to filling of the right atrium, and the x and y descents are attributed to the relaxation of the right atrium/tricuspid valve.


Reference- Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology Edition 26 th Page no 530

questions.text: What results in the Impaired function of aquaporin?
questions.solution:
Diabetes insipidus is a disorder that results from impaired function of aquaporins, which are proteins that form channels in cell membranes and allow water to move in and out of cells. In diabetes insipidus, aquaporins are either missing or are malfunctioning, thus preventing the regulation of the amount of water that can enter cells. As a consequence, too much water enters cells which results in excessive urination and thirst. This is because the kidneys’ ability to reabsorb water is impaired, resulting in reduced concentration of solutes in the body and consequently, an excessive amount of water need to be urinated out of the body in order to keep the solute concentration balanced. Therefore, impaired function of aquaporins can lead to the development of diabetes insipidus due to their essential role in the regulation of water movement in and out of cells.


Reference- Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology Edition 26 th Page no 675

questions.text: Pick the one not included in metabolic syndrome, as per NCEP-ARP III
questions.solution:
• The metabolic syndrome is a group of metabolic and cardiovascular health risks that occur together and increase the risk of developing serious health conditions such as diabetes and heart diseases.
  • The main features of the metabolic syndrome are central obesity, high triglycerides, low levels of high-density lipoprotein (HDL) cholesterol, high blood sugar, and hypertension.
  • People with these risk factors have a significantly higher risk of developing chronic diseases, such as stroke, heart attack, and type 2 diabetes, compared to people without these risk factors.
  • Therefore, diagnosing and treating these abnormalities early are important for preventing related diseases.


Metabolic syndrome criteria: 






Reference: Williams Textbook of Endocrinology, 14th edition, Page no 1608.

questions.text: Where is Pulmonary plethora seen in?
questions.solution:
Pulmonary plethora is a condition in which there is increased pulmonary blood flow, often caused by an abnormal opening in the heart.

  • This can result in enlarged central and peripheral pulmonary arteries and veins in all areas of the lungs.
  • Common causes of pulmonary plethora without cyanosis (blue skin discoloration) are partial anomalous pulmonary venous drainage and large left-to-right shunts due to certain types of congenital heart defects like ASD, VSD, and PDA.
  • On the other hand, the most common cause of pulmonary plethora with cyanosis is total anomalous pulmonary venous drainage (TAPVC).
  • In this condition, the venous blood from the lungs flows directly into the systemic circulation without passing through the left atrium and left ventricle. This can cause cyanosis due to increased oxygen levels in the venous blood, which is not fully oxygenated.
  • In rest all pulmonary oligemia is seen


 

Reference: Essential Pediatrics by OP Ghai, 9th edition, Page no 423, 424.

questions.text: Name the cause for A 20 years old man with hypertension has following CXR finding with aortic shadow as below.
questions.solution:
• The image shows the figure of 3 sign which is seen in the Coarctation of the aorta. It is formed by pre-stenotic dilatation of the aortic arch and left subclavian, indentation at the coarctation site, and post-stenotic dilatation of the descending aorta.
 
  • Coarctation of the aorta refers to the luminal narrowing of a short section of the aorta typically at the site of insertion of the ductus arteriosus. The narrowing of the aorta is thought to occur due to the presence of excessive integrations of ductal tissue around the aortic isthmus.
  • This condition typically presents in teenage or adult patients with seemingly unexplained hypertension and they are at increased risk of additional micro- and macrovascular complications.
  • Individuals with coarctation of the aorta may display symptoms including headaches, nosebleeds, pale skin, tiredness, fainting, and chest pain.
  • Treatment options for Coarctation of the aorta may include medical therapy, balloon angioplasty, or even open surgical aortic reconstruction.


Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 2015.
Essential Pediatrics by OP Ghai, 9th edition, Page no 428, 429.

questions.text: Pick the diagnosis in the kid of A 5 years old child presented to the clinic with h/o of recurrent infections. O/e the child had rashes as shown below. Routine blood investigations revealed the patient had low platelets.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Wiskott Aldrich syndrome

  • Wiskott Aldrich Syndrome (WAS) is a rare X-linked recessive disorder caused by mutations in the WAS Protein Gene.
  • The syndrome is characterized by recurrent infections, eczema, and thrombocytopenia (low platelet count).
     
  • Patients are also at risk for autoimmunity, allergies, and malignancy. WAS is usually diagnosed in infancy, but it can be diagnosed in later life in rare cases.
  • The diagnosis is made with the use of laboratory tests, physical exams, and examining family histories.
  • Treatment typically involves managing infection risk with antibiotics, managing eczema with topical steroids and other treatments, and managing thrombocytopenia with platelet transfusions and/or immunomodulatory medications. Bone marrow transplantation may also be an option for some patients.

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 246.

questions.text: What is the name of the pigment causing Greenish-black color in thick stool passed by neonate after delivery?
questions.solution:
• The first stool that a neonate passes and is greenish-black in color and thick in consistency is called as Meconium.
  • The green hue of meconium is attributable to bile pigments like biliverdin (option 3) that are excreted from the fetal biliary tract.
  • First meconium is usually passed within 24 hours. 
Name of greenish/black stool - Meconium
Pigment responsible for greenish color - Biliverdin

questions.text: What is the likely diagnosis for a child who presented with fever for > 5 days, conjunctivitis and unilateral cervical Lymphadenopathy ?
questions.solution:
All these features (conjunctivitis/fever/unilateral cervical lymphadenopathy) are suggestive of Kawasaki disease. Kawasaki disease is an acute, medium-vessel vasculitis of childhood. Diagnosis requires Fever ≥ 5 days plus ≥4/5 clinical criteria (conjunctivitis, rash, extremity changes, oral mucosal changes, cervical lymphadenopathy). 

This child already has fever, conjunctivitis, and cervical lymphadenopathy - the pattern is  strongly suggestive of Kawasaki.



Other options
  • Option 2 -Scarlet fever - Caused by Strep pyogenes (erythrogenic toxin). Presents with fever, sore throat, sandpaper rash, strawberry tongue, does not cause conjunctivitis or isolated unilateral lymphadenopathy.
 
  • Option 3 - Measles - Presents with high fever, cough, coryza, conjunctivitis, Koplik spots, followed by maculopapular rash starting on face. Doesnot cause unilateral lymphadenopathy. 
 
  • Option 4 - Henoch–Schönlein Purpura (HSP)presents with  - Palpable purpura (lower limbs), abdominal pain, arthritis and renal involvement. 

Reference- Nelson textbook of Pediatrics 21st edition Page No 1314-1316

questions.text: Where is the highest oxygen concentration found in a fetus
questions.solution:
• Correct Option is 2: IVC The placenta through the umbilical vein provides oxygenated blood to the fetus. The umbilical vein through ductus venosus bypasses the liver and opens into IVC. Thus, IVC carries oxygenated blood and has the highest oxygen concentration among the options given above.
  • Superior Vena Cava (SVC): This carries deoxygenated blood from the upper body, so it has a low oxygen concentration.
  • Lungs: The fetal lungs are not yet functioning for gas exchange, so they have very low oxygen concentrations.
  • Aorta: The aorta carries mixed blood (oxygenated from the IVC and deoxygenated from the SVC and ductus arteriosus), so its oxygen concentration is lower than that of the IVC above the ductus venosus.

 

Reference:Nelson textbook of pediatrics 21st edition Page no 2344,2345

Here the respiratory rate of a 2 year old child is >40 which is classified as fast breathing.

questions.text: Where is "remote afterloading" used in?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Brachytherapy.
  • Remote afterloading is a technique used in brachytherapy, a form of internal radiation therapy. In this method, radioactive sources are placed inside or near the tumor using specialized applicators, but the actual insertion of the radiation source is done remotely after positioning the applicator. This helps protect healthcare workers from unnecessary radiation exposure.
  • Brachytherapy is most commonly used in cervical cancer. 
Reference: Walter & Miller's Textbook of Radiotherapy, 7th edition, Page no 197.

questions.text: Mention Cystic lesion in suprasellar region with calcification.
questions.solution:
Correct option is 1: Craniopharyngioma.

The classical history of a cystic suprasellar mass with calcification points towards diagnosis of craniopharyngioma. 

  • Craniopharyngioma is divided into two morphological types- adamantinomatous craniopharyngiomas and papillary craniopharyngiomas.
  • Both are relatively benign WHO grade 1 tumors that typically arise in sellar/suprasellar region.
  • Adamantinomatous craniopharyngiomas- Characterized as cystic masses with peripheral calcifications in children.
  • Papillary craniopharyngiomas- Present as mostly solid masses in adults. 

Craniopharyngiomas are diagnosed through contrast-enhanced MRI scans and CT scans, which help to identify the presence of solid and cystic components, as well as calcification which is present in 80% of these tumors. Physical symptoms such as compression of the optic chiasm or raised intracranial pressure (ICP) are often seen in those with craniopharyngiomas. Treatment approaches for craniopharyngiomas may involve surgery, radiation, drug treatment or a combination of these treatments.



Reference: Grainger & Allison's Diagnostic Radiology, 7th edition, Page no 1418, 1430, 1435, 1437, 1438.

questions.text: Pick the cause when there is no h/o trauma involved in a 45 years old female with sudden onset headache and neck rigidity.
questions.solution:
Correct option is 1: SAH , as in the CT scan hemorrhage is seen in the fissures that is the subarachnoid space. 
  • Subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH) is a medical emergency that occurs due to bleeding into the subarachnoid space, characterized by a sudden and severe headache, sometimes described as "the worst headache of life."
  • Neck rigidity (stiff neck) is a common symptom of SAH, as the bleeding can irritate the meninges, the protective membranes around the brain and spinal cord.
  • SAH can occur spontaneously, and in many cases, there may be no history of trauma or injury involved.


Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 3355.

questions.text: Mention the sign is seen on USG when the femoral vein meets the GSV and femoral artery at saphenofemoral junction.
questions.solution:
Correct option is 1: Mickey mouse sign.
 
  • The Mickey Mouse sign demonstrates the normal anatomy of the common femoral artery, common femoral vein and great saphenous vein on ultrasound just inferior the inguinal crease. 


Option B- String Sign 
  • Gastrointestinal string sign/string sign of Kantor) is string-like appearance of contrast-filled bowel loop due to its severe narrowing.
  • It was originally used to describe reversible narrowing caused by spasms in Crohn disease, 
  • However, it is now used for severe narrowing of the bowel lumen for any etiology such as:
    • Hypertrophic pyloric stenosis
    • Gastrointestinal tuberculosis
    • Carcinoid tumor
    • Colon cancer.
Option C- Tillaux sign is seen in mesenteric cyst where the cyst shows mobility perpendicular to the line of attachment of mesentery. 

Option D- Stemmer Sign is seen in lymphedema wherein skin on dorsum of toes cannot be pinched due to fibrosis. 


Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th edition, Page no 1031.

questions.text: A 35 year old man presets with recurrent episodes of fever with chills and fatigue, an MRCP image is given. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 1: Primary sclerosing cholangitis.

The given MCRP image shows multiple short segment strictures with intervening biliary tree appearing normal/mildly dilated (beading). This along with clinical history of recurrent episodes of fever with chills points towards diagnosis of primary sclerosing cholangitis. 

Thick-slab oblique coronal MRCP is a type of imaging that shows multiple intrahepatic and extrahepatic segments of stricturing. This type of imaging is useful in diagnosing primary sclerosing cholangitis (PSC), an inflammatory disease that affects the bile ducts inside and outside the liver. PSC is characterized by the narrowing and scarring of the bile ducts that can lead to cirrhosis, liver cancer, and other serious complications. The thick-slab oblique coronal MRCP shows evidence of multiple intrahepatic and extrahepatic segments of stricturing which is typical for a PSC diagnosis.

Atypical p- ANCA is positive. Onion skin appearance on HPE. Ulcerative colitis is sometimes associated.


Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th edition, Page no 1241, 1254, 1255.
Sabiston Textbook of Surgery, 21st edition, Page no 1503, 1504.

questions.text: Mention the further step when a patient presents with h/o thickening of skin and shortness of breath and B/L basal rales. Her CXR shows reticular opacities in B/L basal fields.
questions.solution: HRCT (High Resolution Computed Tomography) is an imaging technique that utilizes X-ray technology to produce detailed scans of the lungs. In patients with suspected chronic or acute diffuse lung disease, HRCT is used to better detect and/or diagnose the condition. In patients with suspected chronic diffuse lung disease, HRCT is indicated in the following situations: to detect abnormalities in patients with normal or equivocal plain CXR appearances who have symptoms or pulmonary function tests suggestive of diffuse lung disease, to attempt a specific diagnosis, to assess activity of disease, and to select an optimal biopsy site. In patients with suspected acute diffuse lung disease, HRCT is indicated to detect abnormalities in patients with normal or equivocal plain CXR appearances who have symptoms or pulmonary function tests suggestive of acute lung disease, to investigate hemoptysis in select patients, and to select an optimal biopsy site.

questions.text: A 40 year old male presented to ED with complaints of abdominal colic and features of obstructive jaundice. His WBC counts and liver enzymes were elevated. Ultrasound revealed a scleroatrophic gallbladder with impacted stones in CBD and IHBR dilatation. What is the most appropriate next step of management?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 3. MRCP

The above scenario is a case of Obstructive Jaundice/Surgical Jaundice - Elevated LFT, with a rise in Alkaline phosphatase and an enlarged CBD on radiology.
  • The standard treatment for this type of situation is an Endoscopic Retrograde Cholangiopancreatogram (ERCP) to cut the sphincterotomy and the retrieval of stones in the common bile duct (CBD).
  • After the procedure, a stent can be placed to alleviate the obstruction, followed by a laparoscopic cholecystectomy.
  • Magnetic Resonance Cholangiopancreatogram (MRCP) is a very sensitive and specific diagnostic study that can be used to detect hepatobiliary pathologies.
  • CT scan- Not well suited for detecting uncomplicated stones but excellent for detecting complications such as abscess, perforation of gallbladder or BD, and pancreatitis, Spiral CT may prove useful as a noninvasive means of excluding BD stones; some studies suggest improved diagnostic accuracy when CT is combined with an oral cholecystographic contrast agent.
     
Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 1196.

questions.text: Which among the following is true about structure of protein
questions.solution:
A protein has four levels of structure:
  • primary,
  • secondary,
  • tertiary, and
  • quaternary.
 
  • The primary structure of a protein is the sequence of amino acids.
  • The secondary structure of a protein is the specific arrangement of its amino acids in terms of hydrogen bonds and other intra- or intermolecular interactions.
  • The tertiary structure of a protein is the three-dimensional shape that it adopts in its native state. It is stabilized by the arrangement of side chains, known as the hydrophobic effect, and by the formation of hydrogen bonds, salt bridges, and disulfide bonds.
  • The quaternary structure of a protein refers to two or more protein molecules that come together and interact to form a larger functional unit.
  • Denaturation appears as a change in the shape of the protein molecule caused by the unfolding of its secondary and tertiary structures so that the primary structure remains intact. This causes the loss of all of the protein's native functions. Disulfide bonds, which are part of the tertiary structure, may also be broken in the process.

Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 31st Edition, Page no 34.

questions.text: What is the characteristic finding of fungal ulcer?
questions.solution:
Satellite lesions are pathognomonic of fungal keratitis, which is an inflammation of the cornea caused by fungal infection.

  • It is a secondary complication in which an inflamed area of the cornea is surrounded by an area of uninfected but inflamed tissue.
  • This typically occurs when a fungal infection has spread to the cornea from an adjacent area of the eyelid or eye socket.
  • This type of lesion is seen often in Aspergillus species and can lead to a decrease in vision if not treated.
Other options:- 
  • Dendritic ulcer is seen in HSV keratitis
  • Ring abscess is seen in Acanthamoeba keratitis
  • White hypopyon seen in both bacterial and fungal corneal ulcer hence not specific 


Reference: Ophthalmology by Yanoff and Duker, 5th edition, Page no 227.
Parson’s diseases of the eye, 23rd edition, Page no 175.

questions.solution:

questions.text: What is the prerequisite for sympathetic ophthalmitis?
questions.solution:
• Sympathetic ophthalmitis is a rare pathologic process characterized by bilateral uveitis following injury to one eye either from surgery or penetrating ocular trauma.
  • The penetrating trauma triggers an auto-immune response to the eye which causes inflammation, redness, swelling, and pain.
  • In order to diagnose sympathetic ophthalmitis, the initial penetrating trauma needs to be identified and ruled out, as the condition itself cannot be confirmed without it.



Reference: Ophthalmology by Yanoff and Duker, 5th edition, Page no 770.

questions.text: Which corneal layer contributes to keep the cornea dehydrated?
questions.solution:
Endothelium is a thin layer of cells that lines the inside of blood vessels and serves as a barrier between the bloodstream and surrounding tissues.
  • The endothelium is usually only about 5 millimeters (mm) thick. It is composed of a single layer of flat polygonal cells that are highly metabolically active. It regulates the movement of substances, regulates blood pressure.
  • It contains an "active pump" mechanism called Na+-K+-ATPase to maintain the cornea in a dehydrated state. This pump helps to regulate the water content of the eye, which helps to maintain its shape and avoid dehydration.
  • The endothelium also produces anti-inflammatory substances that reduce inflammation throughout the body.


Reference: Ophthalmology by Yanoff and Duker, 5th edition, Page no 157.

questions.text: What is the additional layer of cilia behind the grey line?
questions.solution:
Distichiasis is a condition characterized by the presence of an extra row of cilia at the opening of the meibomian gland, which is located posterior to the grey line.

  • It is sometimes referred to as second row of eyelashes.
  • The condition can be either acquired or congenital.
  • Acquired distichiasis is caused by metaplasia and dedifferentiation of meibomian glands, typically due to chronic ocular inflammation, such as ocular cicatricial pemphigoid. It typically presents itself as crops of stunted lashes originating from meibomian gland orifices.
  • Congenital distichiasis, on the other hand, is a rare, bilateral, and hereditary condition. It is characterized by the presence of a partial or complete second row of lashes originating from or slightly behind the meibomian gland orifices.



Reference: Comprehensive Ophthalmology by AK Khurana, 7th edition, Page no 386.

questions.text: What is U/L proptosis with B/L sixth nerve palsy?
questions.solution:
Unilateral Proptosis with bilateral abducent Nerve Palsy is seen in cavernous sinus thrombosis.
 

  • It is a condition in which the abducens nerves on both sides of the head become paralyzed, resulting in one eye remaining turned outwards.
  • This is due to compression of the cavernous sinus, a blood-filled channel located in the skull, because of a blood clot.
  • Symptoms include facial pain, double vision and drooping of one of the eyelids.
  • Treatment typically involves anticoagulation therapy to dissolve the clot. In some cases, neurosurgical intervention or radiation therapy may also be helpful.


Reference: Parsons' Diseases of the Eye, 23rd edition, Page no 439.

questions.text: Shifting fluid sign is seen in:
questions.solution:
• Exudative Retinal Detachment (ERD): An exudative retinal detachment (which is often caused by a choroidal tumour) is characterized by shifting subretinal fluid and separated retinal layers. This fluid accumulates due to leakage from blood vessels, fluid in the space below the retina, or overproduction of fluid within the retina itself. 
     
  • Tractional Retinal Detachment: This type of retinal detachment is caused by an abnormal adherence or adhesion between different layers of the retina. It is characterized by retinal mobility being severely reduced, and no shifting subretinal fluid present. The retinal tissue remaining attached could cause the retina to become stretched or pulled away from its underlying layer. 
     
  • Rhegmatogenous Retinal Detachment (RRD): This type of detachment occurs when a hole or tear develops in the retina and fluid from the vitreous space passes through the hole or tear, causing the retina to lift away from the retinal pigment epithelium.


 

Reference: Ophthalmology by Yanoff and Duker, 5th edition, Page no 650.

questions.text: What is Accomodative Esotropia most commonly associated with
questions.solution:
Correct option: 1. Hyperopia
 
  • Accommodative esotropia is the most common esodeviation in children and is characterized by two mechanisms simultaneously occurring in the same individual. The first mechanism is high hyperopia, with an average of +4.50 D, and the second is a tendency for larger esodeviation at near fixation. This mechanism is called a high accommodative convergence-to-accommodation (AC/A) ratio.
  • Hypermetropia/ Hyperopia is a condition caused when the parallel rays of light coming from the infinity are focused behind the retina when accommodation is at rest. This causes vision to be blurry. Some potential complications associated with hypermetropia include recurrent styes, blepharitis and chalazion, which can result from frequent rubbing of the eyes to relieve fatigue and tiredness.
  • Accommodative esotropia can occur due to excessive use of accommodation to see close objects, as there is an increased convergence and miosis in the eye. Hypermetropia carries a higher risk of developing amblyopia compared to myopia. It is also associated with a higher risk of developing primary angle closure glaucoma due the smaller size and more shallower anterior chamber.

Reference: Ophthalmology by Yanoff and Duker, 5th edition, Page no 1212, 1213.

questions.text: Which option is Lesion producing incongruous Homonymous Hemianopia with Wernicke's hemianopic pupil?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 1. Optic tract

Wernicke's Hemianopic Pupil (or Pupillary hemiakinesia) is a type of afferent pupillary conduction defect caused by an optic tract lesion.

  • It is a disorder of the eye's nerve pathways that run to the brain. Specifically, an optic tract lesion causes an impairment of pupillomotor fibers, which pass through the brachium of the superior colliculus before terminating in the pretectal nuclei.
  • As a result, the affected eye will have a pupillary response when the other eye is stimulated, but the response is significantly reduced. This is often accompanied by decreased or absent vision in the affected eye.


Reference: Ophthalmology by Yanoff and Duker, 5th edition, Page no 919.

questions.text: A 65-year-old male with h/o of diabetes comes to the emergency room complaining of diplopia and a squint. Upon examination, it is discovered that the secondary deviation is greater than the primary deviation. Which of the following diagnoses is more likely
questions.solution:
Correct option: 1. Paralytic squint
 
  • The secondary deviation (deviation when the affected eye fixates on an object) is greater than the primary deviation (deviation when the unaffected eye fixates on an object) in Incomitant squint. Incomitant quint can be Paralytic or Restrictive. So, In paralytic or restrictive squint, 2° deviation > 1° deviation.
  • Moreover, the patient is a known diabetic, so prone towards nerve palsy.
  • Based on these findings, the most appropriate answer should be Paralytic squint than restrictive squint.
  • In paralytic squint, there is paralysis or weakness of one or more extraocular muscles, causing an abnormal eye alignment. Paralytic squint is characterized by a greater secondary deviation compared to the primary deviation. Whereas in Non-paralytic or Comitant squint, Primary deviation is equal to secondary deviation.





Reference: Ophthalmology by Yanoff and Duker, 5th edition, Page no 1200.
Comprehensive Ophthalmology by AK Khurana, 7th edition, Page no 365, 371.

questions.text: Which nerve is affected when the movement is lost in the primary gaze?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 2. Abducens Nerve palsy
  • Sixth nerve (Abducens) palsy results in paralysis of Lateral rectus muscle which is the principal abductor of eyeball.
  • Therefore, Abducens nerve palsy manifests as esotropia (adduction) which almost always affects the primary position.
  • The esotropia of a sixth nerve palsy initially exhibits the typical incomitance of a paralytic strabismus; the deviation is maximized in ipsilateral horizontal gaze and smallest in opposite gaze


Reference: Ophthalmology by Yanoff and Duker, 5th edition, Page no 1233.

questions.text: Women in their middle years who have B/L proptosis, restricted ocular motility, and chemosis. Lab investigations reveal abnormal thyroid function. What's the likely diagnosis
questions.solution:
Correct option: 2. Thyroid ophthalmopathy

Thyroid Eye Disease (TED) is the most common cause of unilateral and bilateral proptosis in adults.
  • It has been associated with smoking and affects women five times more than men.
  • It can be present with any thyroid status, including hyperthyroid/ hypothyroid/ euthyroid and can even occur in the absence of clinical and biochemical evidence of thyroid dysfunction.
  • Clinical features can include proptosis, soft tissue involvement, lid retraction, congestion and edema of the conjunctiva and eyelids, restricted ocular ductions with diplopia, and dysthyroid optic neuropathy (DON), resulting from apical compression of the optic nerve by the swollen muscles. The most frequent symptoms are pain and discomfort and a CT scan may reveal thickening of the extra ocular muscles with sparing of the tendons.
Diagnosis:

Diagnosis of TED is based on three aspects of the disease:
(i) Clinical Features: Characteristic findings such as lid retraction combined with proptosis and limited motility are highly suggestive of TED, particularly when bilateral.
(ii) Thyroid Function and Antibody Tests: Abnormal thyroid function tests (thyroxine and TSH levels) or a history of thyroid dysfunction help confirm the diagnosis, although 10% of TED patients may be euthyroid at onset. The presence of TSH-R antibodies has high sensitivity for active Graves’ disease.
(iii) Orbital Imaging: Computerized tomography (CT), magnetic resonance imaging (MRI), or ultrasound may help confirm the diagnosis


Reference: Ophthalmology by Yanoff and Duker, 5th edition, Page no 1344, 1345.

questions.text: Which of the following poisons can be detected in bones of an exhumed body?
questions.solution:
• Arsenic is a poison that was used in embalming and preserving bodies over 200 years ago.
  • Arsenic can still be found in the tissues and bones of older exhumed bodies, due to the arsenic seeping in over time. This is because arsenic was used as an insecticide and preservative before the advent of modern embalming methods.
  • When exhumed, the arsenic may still be detected, as it's a chemical that does not decay or break down over time.


Reference: THE ESSENTIALS OF FORENSIC MEDICINE AND TOXICOLOGY, Dr. K.S. NARAYAN REDDY, 33rd Edition, Page No 538.

questions.text: A swollen face was observed in a patient with tongue swelling, and the results are displayed in the image. What is the most likely reason?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 4. Putrefaction
 
  • Putrefaction is the process by which complex organic body tissue breaks down into simpler inorganic compounds or elements due to the action of saprophytic microorganisms or due to autolysis (without bacterial involvement).
  • The first external sign of putrefaction is a greenish discoloration in the right iliac fossa. Internally, the first site of discoloration is the aortic intima and then the underside of the liver.
  • Marbling, a linear branching pattern on the skin, is most commonly noted on the shoulder, root of the limbs, thighs, sides of the abdomen, chest and neck region.
  • Tongue and other organ protrusion occurs due to gas accumulation and organ enlargement.


Reference: THE ESSENTIALS OF FORENSIC MEDICINE AND TOXICOLOGY, Dr. K.S. NARAYAN REDDY, 33rd Edition, Page No 166.

questions.text: The burden of proof in a civil negligence against the doctor lies with
questions.solution:
•  In a civil negligence case, the burden of proof is on the patient to prove that the doctor has breached a duty of care owed to the patient, that it led to the injury or damage sustained, and that it actually caused the damage.
  • The patient must demonstrate that the doctor acted in a way that did not meet the applicable standards of care, that the breach directly led to the injury or damage, and that the injury or damage is real and measurable.
  • The burden of proof then rests with the doctor to prove that he or she acted reasonably and that the injury or damage was caused by factors outside of the doctor's control. If the doctor can prove contributory negligence or that the injury or damage was caused by something else, them the patient may not be able to recover damages.
  • In the case of Res ipsa loquitur, the evidence speaks for itself, and the patient does not need to prove the elements of negligence.
Reference: THE ESSENTIALS OF FORENSIC MEDICINE AND TOXICOLOGY, Dr. K.S. NARAYAN REDDY, 33rd Edition, Page No 37.

questions.text: With which poisoning event, Magnan's symptoms are associated
questions.solution:
Magnan's symptoms, also known as Cocaine bugs, are characterized by a feeling of insects crawling under the skin. Other features that can accompany this condition can include ulceration of the nasal septum due to sniffing, cocainism (an addiction to cocaine) and cocainomania (tolerance up to 10 gm/day of cocaine). The antidote for cocaine poisoning is amyl nitrate.

Reference: THE ESSENTIALS OF FORENSIC MEDICINE AND TOXICOLOGY, Dr. K.S. NARAYAN REDDY, 33rd Edition, Page No 603.

questions.text: Choose the commonly abused substance which causes physical dependence.
questions.solution:
Heroin is a commonly abused substance that causes physical dependence.
It is an opioid drug derived from morphine, and it produces feelings of euphoria and relaxation.
Heroin is highly addictive, and individuals who use it regularly can quickly develop a tolerance, which can lead to increased use and dependence. LSD, amphetamine, and cannabis are also drugs that can be abused, but they are not as commonly associated with physical dependence as heroin. (Psychological dependence can occur)

Reference: THE ESSENTIALS OF FORENSIC MEDICINE AND TOXICOLOGY, Dr. K.S. NARAYAN REDDY, 33rd Edition, Page No 587.
