questions.text: What happens to the hymen in a rape incidence involving a child of 5 years?
questions.solution:
In young children, there are usually few or no signs of general violence due to their lack of understanding of what is happening. Additionally, the hymen is deeply situated in the vagina so the penetration of the adult organ is not possible; the hymen is typically left intact and there is little redness or tenderness of the labia as a result.

Reference: THE ESSENTIALS OF FORENSIC MEDICINE AND TOXICOLOGY, Dr. K.S. NARAYAN REDDY, 33rd Edition, Page No 390.

questions.text: The mother of a 5-year-old kid brought him to the OPD complaining of perineal soreness. When examined, the sample of his perianal region that had been extracted with picric acid revealed yellow crystals of picrate. What kind of test is it?
questions.solution:
Barberio's test is a microcrystal test for detection of spermine (secreted by prostate) in seminal stains. A saturated aqueous or alcoholic solution of picric acid is added to the dried stains and then examined under microscope.
Above reaction will produce yellow needle shaped crystals of spermine picrate. This test can be positive without the presence of spermatozoa. But it tells that the test stain is a seminal stain.

Reference: THE ESSENTIALS OF FORENSIC MEDICINE AND TOXICOLOGY, Dr. K.S. NARAYAN REDDY, 33rd Edition, Page No 434.

questions.text: Tattoo marks are not visible during autopsy as confirmed by relatives. Where tattooing can be check next during autopsy.
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 4. Lymph Nodes

Pigment from tattoo can migrate from tattoo site to the adjacent lymph nodes like in axillary nodes in upper extremity tattoos.
So, a dissection on these lymph nodes can reveal pigment and tattoos can be identified by naked eye during autopsy.

Reference: THE ESSENTIALS OF FORENSIC MEDICINE AND TOXICOLOGY, Dr. K.S. NARAYAN REDDY, 34th Edition, Page No 89.

questions.text: According to the Mental Health Act of 2017, the maximum number of days that a patient can be hospitalised voluntarily to a mental hospital is:
questions.solution:
•  According to The Mental Health Care Act, 2017 of India, Section 20(3) states that in cases of involuntary or supported admission, a person can be admitted for a period of up to 30 days, after which an extension application should be made to the Mental Health Board.
  • If a person with mental illness admitted under section 89 requires continuous admission and treatment beyond thirty days or a person with mental illness discharged under sub-section (15) of that section requires readmission within seven days of such discharge, he shall be admitted in accordance with the provisions of this section.
  • The Mental Health Board can then approve a further extension of admission based on their assessment of the person's condition. The maximum extension period allowed is 180 days.
  • In cases involving minors and persons with disabilities, the MHB is to be consulted prior to admission and the care and treatment of such persons are to be guided by their best interest.
  • The Mental Health Act also provides for the rights of patients during hospitalization, including access to legal representation, communication with family and friends, and the right to refuse treatment under certain circumstances.


Reference: The Mental health Care Act (MHCA) 2017 https://www.indiacode.nic.in/show-data?actid=AC_CEN_12_13_00024_201710_1517807327874&sectionId=6296&sectionno=90&orderno=90#:~:text=(1)%20If%20a%20person%20with,in%20accordance%20with%20the%20provisions

questions.text: A 51-year-old patient arrived at the clinic complaining of hematuria. He was found to have normal blood pressure and pedal edema. Investigations showed the patient had a creatinine level of 9 mg% and no glycosuria. The electron microscopy is shown below. Which of the following investigations should be carried out in order to determine the cause of the disease?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 2. Anti GBM Antibodies
 

  • Anti-GBM antibodies specifically targets the alpha 3 chain of type IV collagen found in the glomerular basement membrane (GBM).
  • In Goodpasture disease, these antibodies cause inflammation in the lungs and kidneys, resulting in a condition known as Rapidly Progressive Glomerulonephritis (RPGN). This can lead to pulmonary hemorrhage in the lungs, as well as to a particular appearance of the kidneys which is called “flea bitten kidneys” upon physical examination.
 
  • Under a microscope, cells called crescents are found in the kidney tissue. Immunofluorescence shows linear patterns of GBM fluorescence for IgG and complement, and electron microscopy reveals ruptures in the GBM.
 
  • Treatment typically involves a combination of plasmapheresis and immunosuppression.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2338, 2339.

questions.text: HIV is diagnosed in a 35-year-old heterosexual patient who complaints of watery diarrhoea. Colonoscopic biopsy is displayed as follows. What is your most likely diagnosis out of the following
questions.solution:
Cryptosporidiosis is a common opportunistic infection in people living with HIV/ AIDS, and is usually experienced as a diarrheal illness. Diagnosis of cryptosporidiosis in an HIV patient typically requires laboratory testing as the symptoms can be quite similar to other conditions. A stool sample is usually collected and tested for the presence of parasites. Microscopy can reveal the presence of the parasite in stool samples, while molecular diagnostic methods such as PCR or antigen testing can offer greater accuracy. If a patient presents with symptoms suggestive of cryptosporidiosis, a doctor may also order blood tests and other imaging tests to rule out other potentially more serious conditions.

Reference: Paniker's Textbook of Medical Parasitology, 8th edition, Page no 98.

questions.text: An individual who was in an accident suffered a fractured middle cranial fossa. Behind the mastoid, there was a bluish purple colour. What is the likely cause of your condition?
questions.solution:
Battle's sign is a bruise at the bottom of the skull, located behind the ear in the mastoid area. It is seen in temporal bone fractures and can indicate a serious injury or fracture. Other common findings of temporal bone fractures include blood in the external auditory canal (EAC), cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) otorrhoea, hemotympanum (blood behind the eardrum), tympanic membrane perforation (TM pertoration), and facial nerve palsy on the affected side. These symptoms may range from mild to severe depending on the extent of the fracture. Battle's sign is a significant indicator of a fracture in the temporal bone and requires further medical assessment.

Reference : P L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck surgery , 7th Edition- page 507

questions.text: Occipitomental x-ray view of paranasal sinuses with closed mouth is also known as
questions.solution:
The Water’s View X-ray position (also known as the Occipitomental view or nose-chin position) is a useful examination technique utilized by physicians. In this technique, the X-ray beam is projected from behind while the patient places their nose and chin on the film with mouth closed. One of its recommended variations is the Pierre's view, which is preferred as it shows the sphenoid sinus more clearly when taken with an open mouth. It is great for evaluating nasal fractures, where one can clearly see the right and left nasal bones, along with their lateral displacement. Additionally, structures such as the maxillary sinuses, frontal sinuses, sphenoid sinus, lygoma, zygomatic arch, nasal bone, frontal process of maxilla, superior orbital fissure, and intratemporal fossa can be clearly seen with this technique.

If the question mentioned open mouth the answer would have been Pierre's view. 

Referece :https://www.instagram.com/neuronapp.in/p/CguiYhuBvhk/

questions.text: As management, partial closure of the nostrils is done in?
questions.solution:
Partial or full closure of the nostrils is done in the management of ozaena because it helps to reduce the amount of air that can enter the nose and sinus area. This helps to reduce the irritation and mucus that can occur in patients with ozaena, thus helping to decrease the severity of the condition. Additionally, the reduction in airflow through the nasal passages helps to reduce the chances of further infection or inflammation developing in the area.Partial or full closure of the nostrils is done in the management of ozaena because it helps to reduce the amount of air that can enter the nose and sinus area. This helps to reduce the irritation and mucus that can occur in patients with ozaena, thus helping to decrease the severity of the condition. Additionally, the reduction in airflow through the nasal passages helps to reduce the chances of further infection or inflammation developing in the area.

 

Young's operation is a surgical treatment used to treat conditions like chronic nasal obstruction and snoring. The procedure involves the closing of both nostrils with the use of elevated vestibule skin flaps. The nostrils are re-opened six months later when the mucosa has returned to normal.

 

Modified Young's operation is a variation of the procedure in which only partial closure is implemented, leaving a 2 mm hole in the nostril to reduce discomfort. 

 

Lastly, Lautenslager surgery is another surgical treatment that involves inserting fat, cartilage, and Teflon under the mucoperiosteum of the lateral wall in order to narrow the widened airway.


Reference : P L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck surgery , 7th Edition- page 173

questions.text: Coughing is caused by external auditory canal stimulation and involves which nerve?
questions.solution:
The Auricular branch of Vagus nerve, known as Arnold's Nerve, supplies the concha (the pocket in the external ear), the posterior wall and floor of the external ear canal. Stimulation of the Vagus nerve during probing can lead to a cough reflex or even a slowing of the heart rate (bradycardia). Interestingly, there are also sensory fibers of facial nerve that supply the posterior wall and concha of the external ear through the Vagus nerve fibers. Therefore, when a person has herpes zoster oticus, which is a virus that affects the facial nerve, vesicles may be seen on the concha and the postauricular region.



Reference: Gray's Anatomy The Anatomical Basis Of Clinical Practice Edition 42 nd Page no 1035.e1

questions.text: For parotid surgery, not a surgical landmark?
questions.solution:
• Identifying the facial nerve is done through a variety of methods, both antegrade and retrograde.
  • Antegrade methods involve tracing the nerve from posterior to anterior regions of the head and neck. These methods utilize the tragal pointer (Conley's Pointer), the squamotympanic fissure, the styloid process, and the mastoid process to identify the facial nerve and follow it to its origin deeper in the neck.
  • Retrograde methods involve identifying the buccal or cervical branches of the facial nerve and tracing them backwards. This is particularly useful in re-operative cases.

Reference: SRB's Manual Of Surgery, Sriram Bhat M, 6th Edition, Page No 408.

questions.text: Saccules is developed from which of the following structures?
questions.solution:
The inner structures of the ear, such as the cochlea, the vestibular apparatus, and the acoustic nerve, develop from the surface ectoderm. This happens in two phases: the formation of the otic placode and the subsequent development of the otic vesicle from this ectodermal region. The otic placode is formed during embryonic development, when the ectoderm thickens along the boundaries of the first and second pharyngeal arches. This then develops into the otic vesicle, and continues to develop and differentiate into the structures of the inner ear.

 

The saccule develops from the pars inferior of the utricle, a structure which develops from the saccule. The pars inferior, located at the base of the utricle, is a thin layer of squamous epithelial cells. During development, these cells are replaced by columnar epithelial cells which form the saccule. The saccule then contributes to the development of the cochlea and the auditory tube. The saccule is innervated by the nerve fibers from the vestibular portion of the vestibulocochlear nerve. Additionally, the saccule plays a role in controlling balance and maintaining equilibrium.



Reference: Gray’s Anatomy The Anatomical Basis Of Clinical Practice Edition 42 nd Page no 269

questions.text: A competitive neuromuscular blockade that targets nicotinic receptors was given to a patient. Which of the following medications can be used to counteract its effects after surgery
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Neostigmine
 
  • Neostigmine is used to reverse the effects of muscle relaxants given during surgery that cause muscle paralysis. Neostigmine works by inhibiting the enzyme acetylcholinesterase, which breaks down the neurotransmitter acetylcholine.
  • This leads to an increase in available acetylcholine, allowing muscles to return to their normal activity. Neostigmine is commonly injected intravenously or subcutaneously, and its effects are reversible. The addition of atropine is used to reduce potential adverse effects, such as bradycardia, bronchospasm, and increased secretions.
  • Physostigmine is also acetylcholinesterase blocker but as it is a tertiary amine it crosses BBB, hence is not preferred. It is used in treatment of closed angle glaucoma.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 122.

choices.text: Routine preop + clinical + angiography to look for patency

questions.text: A 55-year-old male patient who underwent a CABG four years ago and has h/o HTN on ACE-inhibitor is scheduled for hernia surgery. He can tolerate effects well. What preoperative investigations would you order?
questions.solution:
• The correct investigation to be ordered for a 55-year-old female patient on ACE inhibitors for hypertension who had CABG 4 years back and is scheduled for hernia surgery is Routine preop and clinical evaluation and angiography to look for patency.
  • Angiography would be used to evaluate the patency of the grafts and ensure that there are no blockages or other issues that could complicate the hernia surgery.
  • Routine preoperative evaluation and clinical examination are standard procedures before any surgery

Reference: Miller's Anesthesia, 9th edition, Page no 933-945,1965.
Morgan and Mikhail's Clinical Anesthesiology, 5th edition, Page no 530.

questions.text: What does the following ETCO2 curve depicts?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 1. Spontaneous efforts
 
  • In an end-tidal CO2 (ETCO2) graph, spontaneous effort typically appears as irregularities or "dips" in the waveform during mechanical ventilation. This is commonly known as "Curare clefts".
  • These dips occur when the patient attempts to breathe independently, causing a disruption in the smooth pattern of the ventilator's delivered breaths.
  • Spontaneous effort might be reflected on an ETCO2 graph:

    1. Dip in the Plateau Phase: Normally, the ETCO2 waveform has a plateau phase after the peak, which represents the alveolar plateau. Spontaneous effort may cause a sudden dip during this phase, indicating the patient’s attempt to inhale against the ventilator.

    2. Inconsistent Waveform: The otherwise regular and consistent waveform might show variability in amplitude or frequency due to the patient's spontaneous breathing efforts.

    3. Increased Frequency: If the patient is making multiple spontaneous efforts, you may see a more frequent waveform pattern, potentially with smaller breaths between the regular ventilator-delivered breaths




Reference: Miller’s Anesthesia, 9th edition, Page no: 1311.

questions.text: A patient from NE India presents with U/L edema. He has had his PCI and is k/c/o CAD. Swelling is more distal than proximal. What is the next best investigation
questions.solution:
The given symptoms are indicative of lymphatic filariasis which is most commonly caused by W. Bancrofti. DEC provoocation test is the initial investigation of choice for detecting microfilariae in the patient’s blood.

Reference: Paniker's Textbook of Medical Parasitology, 8th edition, Page no 215.

choices.text: Monitoring of trends and determinants in cardiovascular disease

questions.text: What is the WHO- MONICA project for cardiovascular diseases associated with?
questions.solution:
• MONICA (Monitoring Trends and Determinants in Cardiovascular Disease) is a long-term, multi-centre, population-based research programme with the primary aim of monitoring risk factors, trends and determinants of cardiovascular diseases (CVD) in Europe.
  • The project is coordinated by the World Health Organisation (WHO) Regional Office for Europe and includes 24 cohorts from 26 countries.
  • The MONICA project focuses on the epidemiology of CVD, the identification of factors associated with atherosclerosis and its risk factors, the development and evaluation of prevention strategies, health education and public health policies.
  • It also provides data from mortality and morbidity surveillance allowing for a comprehensive assessment of the impact of interventions on mortality, morbidity and health-related quality of life.
Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 419.

questions.text: A patient with measles has these clustered white lesions on the buccal mucosa (opposite to the upper first and second molars). These are known as?
In occupational personal radiation, dose monitoring is done by?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: TLD Badge.
  • Thermoluminescent dosimeter is a passive radiation detection device used for personal dose monitoring or to measure patient dose.
  • Certain materials known as phosphors have the tendency to emit light when heated. This property is known as thermoluminescence.
  • Examples of such material include lithium fluoride (LiF), calcium fluoride (CaF2), calcium sulphate (CaSO4), and lithium borate (Li2B4O7) show thermoluminescence.
  • Principle-When a LiF crystal is exposed to radiation, few of the electrons get trapped at higher energy levels. When the crystal is heated, these electrons return to their stable energy levels.
  • The energy differences between the two orbital levels is emitted as light which is then measured by a photomultiplier tube.
  • The amount of light emitted gives an estimate of the radiation dose as the two are proportional.
  • If a radiation worker is wearing a lead apron, the TLD badge can be worn under the lead apron (to reflect body dose) or outside the lead apron (to reflect extremity/thyroid dose). 


Thermoluminescent dosimeters (TLD) are radiation detection devices used for personal dose monitoring or to measure patient dose from external x-ray, gamma and beta radiation. It is a passive radiation detection device that consists of a TLD card loaded in a cassette with suitable metallic filters.

TLD is based on the phenomenon of thermoluminescence, which is the emission of light when certain materials are heated following exposure to radiation. The TLD badge does not protect the wearer from radiation, but it does measure and detect the radiation to which a person has been exposed.



Reference: Walter & Miller's Textbook of Radiotherapy, 7th edition, Page no 49-51.

questions.text: Choose which is not a radiographic finding seen in CHF?
questions.solution:
• Focal oligemia is not a radiological sign of left heart failure; rather, it is associated with pulmonary embolism and is referred to as Westermark's sign. 
 
  • This condition is characterized by a hyperlucent area in the lung with reduced vascularity due to oligemia. It results from a disruption of circulation caused by an embolus, leading to the absence of visible pulmonary vasculature in the affected area on an X-ray.

Radiological features of Left heart failure:
 
  • Cardiomegaly- Refers to the enlargement of the cardiac silhouette, indicated by an increased cardiothoracic ratio.
  • Upper lobe pulmonary venous congestion, characterized by cephalization of vessels, and interstitial edema is present.
  • Kerley B lines appear as horizontal lines in the peripheral regions of the lower posterior lung fields, as illustrated below.


Reference: Grainger & Allison's Diagnostic Radiology, 6th edition, Page no 374, 375.

questions.text: What is the next step in management for a 70-year-old unstable male with h/o HTN and DM who acquired the following rhythm with a B.P. of 90/60 mmHg and a weak pulse
questions.solution:
ECG shows uniform narrow QRS complex tachycardia suggestive of PSVT.
 
  • DC cardioversion is a procedure used to treat abnormal heart rhythms. It involves the application of a direct electrical current to the heart through paddles or electrodes placed on the chest wall.
  • This electrical current causes the heart to reset its rhythm to normal, which is why it is used in the case of wide QRS monomorphic ventricular tachycardia.
  • Since the patient is clinically unstable, with a blood pressure (BP) of 90/60 mmHg, it is imperative that the immediate treatment is DC cardioversion to restore normal rhythm and prevent further harm.


Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 1919.

questions.text: After undergoing B/L adrenalectomy due to B/L pheochromocytoma, the patient experienced  lethargy, exhaustion, low blood pressure, and normal pulse 1 day later. There are no indications of volume deficiency, what is the likely cause?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Addisonian Crisis

  • Pheochromocytomas and paragangliomas are tumors which are derived from the sympathetic or parasympathetic nervous system and produce catecholamines.
  • The ultimate treatment goal for these tumors is complete removal of the tumors, which can be done through partial or total adrenalectomy. However, it is important that the normal adrenal cortex is still there, in order to prevent Addison's disease and to make sure that bilateral pheochromocytomas are most likely to be present.
  • Nitroprusside infusion is used for any intraoperative hypertension and hypotension can be solved with a volume infusion. Postoperatively, the catecholamine levels should be checked to make sure they are normalized.
  • An ACTH test should be done to check for cortisol deficiency when bilateral adrenal cortex-sparing surgery is done. The risks of surgery for pheochromocytoma include severe preoperative hypertension, high secretion tumors and recurrence.
  • Additionally, the absence of adrenal glands can lead to a sharp drop in cortisol which requires lifelong glucocorticoid replacement therapy which leads to a 15-25% risk of developing Nelson syndrome.
  • Nelson syndrome is characterized by the enlargement of the pituitary gland and the development of pituitary gland tumors.

Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 898.

choices.text: Rheumatic heart disease is an uncommon cause

questions.text: Patient with atrial fibrillation which is false.
With which temperature, frostbite rapid rewarming is done?
questions.solution: Frost bite is a type of cold burn that is caused by exposure to very low temperatures. It is commonly found on body parts such as fingers, toes, cheeks, the tip of the nose, and ears. When the tissue freezes, it will become hard and cannot be indented. In order to treat frost bite, the frozen area needs to be warmed gently and slowly. The recommended temperature to warm the area is around 42 degrees Fahrenheit as too much heat may also cause a burn. In some cases, the exposure to the cold can be so severe that it may cause permanent damage.

questions.text: Deficiency of what led to this?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Vit. B12 deficiency
 
  • Pernicious anemia (PA) is an autoimmune macrocytic anemia caused by a vitamin B12 deficiency due to a lack of intrinsic factor which is an important factor for the absorption of B12 in the small intestine.
  • Vitamin B12 deficiency can lead to neurological symptoms such as paresthesia, and a decreased Hemoglobin (Hb) value of 6gm% is a sign of anemia.
  • Characteristic features seen on a peripheral smear that occurs due to megaloblastic anemia can include macrocytes, and neutrophils with hyper segmented nuclei.
  • Endoscopy findings can reveal atrophy of gastric mucosa, which can result in decreased absorption of vitamin B12 due to a lack of intrinsic factor, and therefore lead to its deficiency.

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 652.

questions.text: After a day of fasting, a BPD patient who has been taking lithium for six months experiences seizures, coarse tremors, ataxia, and limb weakness. What is the most reliable way to diagnose her illness?
questions.solution: Based on the symptoms described, the most likely cause of the BPD patient's illness is lithium toxicity. The most reliable way to diagnose this would be to measure the patient's serum lithium levels. Therefore, the correct answer is option 2 (S. Lithium).

questions.text: A patient with ADPKD using TOLVAPTAN has symptoms of stomach ache and loose stools. What is the most likely reason for this?
questions.solution: Tolvaptan is a drug used for the treatment of hyponatremia, which is caused by elevated levels of arginine vasopressin (which is also known as antidiuretic hormone, or ADH). This drug has recently been linked to elevated serum amino transferase levels and clinically apparent acute liver injury if used for a long period of time. In other words, long-term use of tolvaptan has been associated with an increased risk of liver damage and complications.

questions.text: Choose what van den Bergh test is for
questions.solution:
The van den Bergh test is a laboratory procedure used to measure bilirubin levels in the blood. More specifically it determines the amount of direct/conjugated bilirubin. The direct component of bilirubin is not affected by the test, while the indirect component is. The test uses specific reagents, typically sodium nitrite and diazotized sulfanilic acid, to react with bilirubin and give a red colour with the formation of a diazo compound. The colour intensity on a colour scale from 0 to 5 is compared with standards to get relative proportions of direct and indirect bilirubin. This test can be used to measure the proportion of each component of bilirubin in newborns with jaundice and monitor the efficacy of phototherapy.

 

Reference-:Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition Page no 316

questions.text: Which of the following is most common form of muscular dystrophies
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) DMD
 
  • Duchenne Muscular Dystrophy (DMD) is the most common hereditary neuromuscular disorder, occurring in an estimated 1 in 3,600 live born infant boys. It is caused by an abnormal gene located at the Xp21.2 locus, which encodes a 427-kDa cytoskeletal protein called dystrophin.
  • The most common molecular defect in DMD is a deletion of the gene, which may be followed by duplication or point mutations. Some female carriers, or affected girls, can experience a mild form of the disorder, due to the Lyon Hypothesis which states that the normal X chromosome becomes silenced, and the one with the gene deletion is active. Girls with Turner Syndrome, a disorder caused by a single X chromosome, have a gene deletion at the Xp21 locus.
  • Characteristic clinical features of DMD includes progressive muscle weakness, intellectual impairment, hypertrophy of the calves, and proliferation of connective tissue in the muscle. Becker muscular dystrophy (BMD) is similar to DMD, but usually has a milder phenotype.
Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 1232.

questions.text:
The patient, a 42-year-old man, had lesions as depicted below.
Which of these is the best course of action for treating this condition?
questions.solution:
• The given image shows Leonines facies (thickened nodular lesions on foreheard, ears, eyebrows, and cheeks) seen in and classically described for Lepromatous leprosy.
  • Hence, the patient should be started on MDT for leprosy.
  • In Lepromatous leprosy, the skin and soft tissues of the face can thicken, leading to a lion-like appearance, which is where the term "leonine" comes from.
  • This change is due to the effects of the disease on the skin and underlying tissues, including loss of eyebrows and changes in the nose's structure.


Reference- Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Page number 28.9

questions.text: What is the phenomenon shown in the image below?
questions.solution: The Koebner Phenomenon, also known as Isomorphic Phenomenon, is a condition where an injury or trauma to the skin can trigger certain skin conditions, primarily psoriasis, lichen planus, and vitiligo. This phenomenon occurs when an area of uninvolved skin is traumatized, triggering the development of morphologically similar lesions, or skin changes. It is believed that this phenomenon is in response to the presence of an underlying inflammatory or autoimmune skin disorder. In most cases, the affected skin will appear slightly paler than normal and may be slightly itchy. The lesions typically exhibit a similar pattern of inflammation or discoloration to the injured area. It is important to note that this phenomenon occurs only in individuals with an underlying skin disorder and that it should not be used as a diagnosis for underlying conditions, as it is merely a sign of the disorder.

questions.text: Which of the following is a likely diagnosis based on the image given below?
questions.solution:
• Acute Cutaneous LE refers to any cutaneous (skin) manifestation of lupus that appears suddenly and typically is inflammatory in nature (red, itchy, swollen, etc.).
  • These lesions often appear as patches, plaques, and/or lesions, which can be widespread or localized.
  • Subacute Cutaneous LE refers to a form of cutaneous LE that may appear as red patches, plaques, scaly or ulcerative lesions that can have an inflammatory, noninflammatory, or mixed presentation.
  • Chronic Cutaneous LE refers to a type of Cutaneous LE that has been present for a long period of time and can cause disfigurement of the skin.
  • DLE (Discoid Lupus Erythematosus) is the most common form of cutaneous LE and presents as erythematous to depigmented discoid plaque with adherent scaling usually occurring over face, scalp, neck and 'V' area of chest.
Skin manifestations in SLE


Reference- Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Page number 51.2

questions.text: A patient comes to your OPD with the following lesion which was associated with itching. The most likely diagnosis is?
questions.solution:
• Tinea corporis, also known as ringworm, is a fungal skin infection typically caused by a type of fungus known as dermatophytes.
  • It typically presents as an itchy, annular (ring-shaped) plaque with well-defined borders, peripheral papulopustular, scaling, and central clearing.
  • The most common organism responsible for this infection is a type of dermatophyte named Trichophyton rubrum.
Trick: -
Annular lesion with central clearing- Tinea
Annular lesion with central scarring- Lupus vulgaris
Annular lesion with central crusting- Cutaneous leishmaniasis 

Reference- Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Page number 32.35, 32.36, 31.26

questions.text: After a 3-day CT revealed an SDH, the patient with h/o RTA presented to the OPD. Fundoscopy revealed B/L papilledema. What is the likelihood of this happening?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 1: Raised ICT
  • Papilledema is a swelling of the optic disc, caused by increased intracranial pressure (ICP), which is the pressure of the cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) inside the skull.
  • In the case, the patient has a history of RTA, and a CT scan has revealed an SDH. 
  • SDH is a collection of blood between the dura mater, meninges, and the arachnoid mater. This collection of blood can increase ICP, which can lead to papilledema.

Other options : 
  • Meningitis, Optic neuritis, and Glaucoma are less likely causes, as they are not directly related to the history of RTA and SDH.



Reference: Parsons' Diseases of the Eye, 23rd edition, Page no 323-325.

choices.text: Stop the current antidepressants and add mood stabiliser

questions.text: When a woman with h/o depression visited the OPD, imipramine was administered. A week later, passers by complained that she was talking too much and experiencing hallucinations. What tips do you have for follow-up
questions.solution:
• If a person is identified to be at risk for developing either mania or hypomania when taking tricyclics (like given in clinical scenario - talking too much/experiencing hallucinations), the first step would be to stop the current antidepressant.
  • Mania and hypomania require specialized treatment with mood stabilizers.
  • Tricyclic antidepressants can cause profound changes in mood and can be dangerous/exacerbate the manic episode in vulnerable individuals.
  • By stopping the current antidepressant, a person is taking the first step in avoiding these potentially dangerous effects.
  • The ideal management would be to stop the anti depressant followed by adding mood stabiliser along with second generation anti- psychotic. Hence the best answer would be option 1


Reference: Kaplan and Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page no 375, 378, 379.

questions.text: A first-year MBBS who was complaining of periodic episodes of a sense of impending doom and extreme perspiration visited the OPD. The events typically happen just before her examinations. Which diagnosis is more likely?
questions.solution:
• Panic attack is a sudden period of intense fear or apprehension that can last for minutes or hours.
  • People with panic disorder may have recurrent unexpected panic attacks without a trigger.
  • Common symptoms of a panic attack are extreme fear, a sense of impending doom, and anticipatory anxiety.
  • Other causes of panic attacks include exposure to certain panicogen substances such as carbon dioxide, yohimbine, cholecystokinin, and caffeine. This can also cause a situational predisposed panic attack in response to a trigger.


Reference: Kaplan and Sadock's Concise Textbook of Clinical Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page no 394.

questions.text: A 74-year-old man with ataxia and urine incontinence was brought to the OPD by his daughter.  He struggles with simple maths calculations and suffers from memory loss. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Normal Pressure Hydrocephalus (NPH) is a form of communicating hydrocephalus, characterized by an enlarged ventricular system and normal opening pressures on lumbar puncture.
  • It is associated with a classic set of symptoms including a triad of dementia, gait disturbance and urinary incontinence.
  • Idiopathic NPH may be caused by decompensated congenital hydrocephalus or impaired absorption of cerebrospinal fluid.
  • Secondary NPH is caused by intraventricular or subarachnoid hemorrhage, acute or chronic meningitis, Paget disease at the skull base or other rare conditions.
  • The most prominent symptom is gait difficulty, which is distinguished from Parkinsonian gait by a wide base, small steps and postural instability.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 175, 194.

questions.text: A 25-year-old man who complained of chronic mouth ulcers and congested eyes was seen in the OPD. Inquiries revealed that he had h/o prior hospitalization for venous thrombosis. What illness is he dealing with exactly
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Behcet's disease
 
  • The patient is dealing with Behcet's disease.
  • Behcet's disease is a systemic autoimmune disorder characterized by recurrent oral ulcers, genital ulcers, and eye inflammation (conjunctivitis/uveitis).
  • In addition, it can cause blood vessel inflammation, leading to thrombosis and other systemic manifestations.

* The international criteria for Behçet disease scoring system

Sign/Symptom Points
Ocular lesions 2
Genital aphthosis 2
Oral aphthosis 2
Skin lesions 1
Neurological manifestations 1
Vascular manifestations 1
Positive pathergy test 1

* Patients with a score of < 3 were considered as not having BD.
* A score of 3 was considered probable BD, and a score of ≥4 indicated a definitive diagnosis of BD. 

Online Reference:
Adil A, Goyal A, Quint JM. Behcet Disease. [Updated 2023 Feb 22]. In: StatPearls [Internet]. Treasure Island (FL): StatPearls Publishing; 2024 Jan-. Available from: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK470257/

questions.text: A 4-year-old unvaccinated patient with fever and red eyes arrived at OPD. The patient's body was covered in the following form of rash at the time. What complication associated with this condition is most likely to occur
questions.solution:
• A history of no vaccination along with fever and a maculopapular rash is suggestive of Measles.
  • The most common complication associated with measles infection is Acute Otitis Media. Complications associated with measles include: Otitis media (most common) Bronchopneumonia (most severe) Hecht’s pneumonia/ giant cell pneumonia Subacute sclerosis panencephalitis (chronic, fatal)

Reference-Ghai Essential Pediatrics 9th Edition Page no 209,210

questions.text: Hypothyroidism is now evident in the patient with h/o DM, and she is not gaining weight. What has to be done in terms of additional diagnostic research
questions.solution:
Correct option: 1. Anti TPO antibodies
 
  • Hashimoto thyroiditis is an autoimmune disorder in which the body's immune system attacks the thyroid gland, causing inflammation and damage to the thyroid cells.
  • This destruction and damage leads to a decrease in the production of thyroid hormones.
  • It is the most common cause of hypothyroidism in areas where iodine is not deficient.
  • It is more commonly found in women than in men. It is associated with the presence of autoantibodies against thyroglobulin and thyroid peroxidase (TPO), and there is a genetic component linked to the genes CTLA4 and PTPN22.
  • Histologically, the thyroid gland shows a mononuclear infiltrate, atrophic thyroid follicles and Hurthle cells.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2933, 2934.

choices.text: Failure of migration of Neural crest cells

questions.text: Hirschsprung disease is caused due to:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Failure of migration of Neural crest cells
 
  • Hirschsprung disease is caused due to failure of migration of neural crest cells during embryonic development.
  • Histopathological findings include the absence of ganglion cells in the affected segment of the colon.
  • Accumulation of fecal material above the aganglionic segment leads to distension of the colon.
  • PR examination lead to expulsion of feaces. 
  • Biopsy reveals hypertrophic nerve trunks and increased number of nerve fibers in the aganglionic segment.
  • The transition zone between the aganglionic and normal segments shows a characteristic "cuff" of hypertrophic nerves.
Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 755.

questions.text: One and a half year old child with history of diet including only rice & milk, had a protruding abdomen, and a low albumin level, but no proteinuria. What is the most likely cause for the above?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Kwashiorkor

The child has protruding abdomen which is likely due to ascites secondary due to albumin loss and a poor diet history. These findings are suggestive of child having Kwashiorkar characterised by visceral protein loss (albumin loss) resulting in ascites, oedema, poor appetite and high mortality. 

  


Other options
  • Option 2 - Marasmus will have muscle protein loss with baggy pant appearance/simian facies and occurs usually in infants (<1y) unlike 1.5 y old child given in question stem. 
  • Option 3 – Nephrotic syndrome will present with massive proteinuria (>40mg/m2/hr), not nil proteinuria as given in question stem. 
  • Option 4 – Poor diet history of rice and milk points more towards protein deficiency leading to kwashiorkor than due to liver failure.

Reference- Nelson Textbook of Pediatrics 21st edition Page no 337, 1310, 2105

questions.text: Which of the following parameters, if found within the normal range for age, most reliably rules out malnutrition?
questions.solution:
• BMI and Skin fold thickness can erroneously be normal in patients having oedema (For eg. Patients with Kwashiorkor may have a normal weight due to water retention and oedema).
  • Hence in such scenarios, only a normal lean body mass which indicates normal body stores of protein and specifically rules out malnutrition.

Reference- https://www.sciencedirect.com/topics/nursing-and-health-professions/lean-body-weight

questions.text: What does not characterise TB otitis media?
questions.solution:
Tubercular otitis media is an infection of the middle ear following pulmonary tuberculosis. Symptoms include painless ear discharge, multiple perforations, severe hearing loss, and in some cases facial paralysis. Diagnosis typically includes observation of pale granulations on examination. Common complications include mastoiditis, labyrinthitis, post-auricular fistula, and osteomyelitis.


Reference : P L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck surgery , 7th Edition- page 81

questions.text: Choose what photostress test is used to differentiate between:
questions.solution:
Correct option: 2. macula and optic nerve
 
  • Photostress recovery time (PSRT) is the time taken for visual acuity to return to normal levels after the retina has been bleached by a bright light source.
  • Photostress recovery time measurement procedure is known as Photostress test. Normal recovery time is about 15–30 seconds.

Purpose: 
  • Can differentiate between retinal and post retinal disease.
  • The photostress test is a simple, easy and quick clinical technique that can differentiate between retinal (macular) and post retinal (e.g. optic nerve) disease.


Reference: Parsons’ Diseases of the Eye, 23rd edition, Page no 89, 90.

questions.text: Patient with A/C onset of left side weakness and loss of sensation over left side of body with facial sparing. On protrusion of tongue, deviates to the right side. Which artery involved
questions.solution: The vertebral artery supplies blood to the brain, running from the innominate and subclavian arteries in four segments (V1-V4). V1-3 pass through the vertebral foramina (C6-C2) and circle around the atlas to reach the foramen magnum, while the fourth segment forms the basilar artery. This serves to supply the brainstem and cerebellum with branches PICA and AICA, respectively.

questions.text: The patient underwent LSCS. Following surgery, the patient experienced constipation, abdominal distention with a soft and silent bowel. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1. Paralytic Ileus

Paralytic ileus occurs from prolonged hypomotility of the gastrointestinal tract secondary to inflammation of intestinal smooth muscle.
  • Ileus, also known as paralytic ileus or functional ileus, occurs when there is a non-mechanical decrease or stoppage of the flow of intestinal contents.
  • Ileus is an often unavoidable consequence of abdominal or retroperitoneal surgery, but can also be found in severely ill patients with septic shock or mechanical ventilation.
  • Moderate to severe cases have been documented in 10-20% of post-cesarean patients. Paralytic ileus refers to abdominal distension, intolerance of oral intake and an inability to pass flatus persisting for more than 3 - 5 days postoperatively.
  • Examination typically reveals a hyper-resonant and distended abdomen, generalized tenderness and reduced to absent bowel sounds.
 Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 325.

questions.text: Which cancer  is likely to present with inguinal lymph node enlargement?
questions.solution:
The inguinal lymph nodes primarily drain the lower limb, perineum, external genitalia (penis or vagina), anal canal (below the pectinate line), and lower abdominal wall. Penile cancer on metastasis will drain into superficial and deep inguinal lymph nodes.

Other options
  • Colorectal cancer drains into mesenteric and iliac lymph nodes.
  • Prostate cancer drains into internal iliac and obturator lymph nodes.
  • Testicular cancer drains into para-aortic (retroperitoneal) lymph nodes.
Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 1444.

questions.text: Choose which is not a symptom of pituitary apoplexy.
questions.solution:
Hypertension is NOT a feature of Pituitary Apoplexy, instead hypotensive shock occurs due to Adrenal insufficiency.
 
  • Pituitary apoplexy is a sudden hemorrhage into the pituitary gland that can be caused by a preexisting adenoma, postpartum syndrome, diabetes, hypertension, sickle cell anemia, or shock.
 
  • Symptoms can include severe headache, diplopia, ophthalmoplegia, hypotension, loss of consciousness, and life-threatening hypotension due to ACTH and cortisol deficiency.
 
  • Diagnosis is usually confirmed with a computed tomography or MRI scan.
 
  • Treatment usually involves high-dose glucocorticoids, but those with significant visual loss, cranial nerve palsy, or loss of consciousness may require urgent surgical decompression.


Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 2897, 2898.

questions.text: After how many hours does a nosocomial infection occur?
questions.solution:
• Hospital-acquired infections (HAI) or nosocomial are infections that are not present or are incubating at the time of a patient's admission to a healthcare setting but become clinically evident 48 hours or more after admission.
  • These infections are caused by viral, bacterial, and fungal pathogens and can lead to bloodstream infection (BSI), pneumonia (e.g., ventilator-associated pneumonia [VAP]), urinary tract infection (UTI), and surgical site infection (SSI).
  • The term 'healthcare-associated infections' is the preferred term to replace older ones like 'nosocomial', 'hospital-acquired', or 'hospital-onset' infections.
Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 648.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a symptom in ACTH deficiency?
questions.solution:
• ACTH deficiencies occur when the body is unable to produce adequate amounts of the hormone ACTH (adrenocorticotropic hormone).
  • This lack of production can be caused by pituitary problems, genetic factors, or the administration of exogenous glucocorticoids. When ACTH levels are decreased, the production of cortisol and aldosterone decreases in turn, which can lead to adrenal atrophy due to the lack of ACTH stimulation.
  • Signs and symptoms of ACTH deficiency are similar to those of Addison's disease and include fatigue, weakness, weight loss, nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea.
  • However, the serum sodium and potassium levels are usually more normal in secondary adrenal insufficiency compared to Addison's disease and there is no presence of hyperpigmentation.


Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2971, 2972.

questions.text: A 65 year old patient is treated in ICU for Acute exacerbation of COPD. Which of the following is false regarding management?
questions.solution:
Incorrect statement is 1. Non-invasive ventilation is not indicated

Non-invasive mechanical ventilation is preferred for patients with acute respiratory failure, as it improves gas exchange, reduces work of breathing and the need for intubation, and can lower hospitalization duration and improve survival.

  • Systemic corticosteroids (Option 4) have been found to improve lung function and reduce recovery time and duration of hospitalization, but treatments should not exceed 5-7 days.
  • Antibiotics, when indicated, can reduce early relapse, treatment failure and hospitalization duration, but should not exceed 5-7 days.
  • Methylxanthines are not recommended due to potential side effects.
  • Supplemental O2 therapy should be provided enough to maintain a target SpO2 of 88-92%.
  • Short-acting inhaled beta-agonists, often in combination with anticholinergics, are recommended as the initial bronchodilators for treatment of an acute exacerbation of COPD. (Option 3)



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2189.

questions.text:
Patient feels warm and is fatigued; they are not gaining weight. o/e the patient has a staring expression and B/L proptosis. Examination will reveal?
1. Low TSH and High T3/T4
2. High TSH and High T3
3. High TSH and Low free T3
4. Normal TSH and High T3
questions.solution:
•  Thyrotoxicosis is over-functioning of the thyroid gland.
  • It can cause weight loss, despite an enhanced appetite due its increased metabolic rate, as well as hyperactivity, nervousness and irritability, tremor, hyperreflexia, muscle wasting, proximal myopathy, sinus tachycardia, palpitations, widened pulse pressure, aortic systolic murmurs, heat intolerance, palmar erythema, onycholysis, pruritus, urticaria, diffuse hyperpigmentation, fine hair texture, diarrhea, oligomenorrhea and amenorrhea, impaired sexual function, gynecomastia and osteopenia.
  • Depending on the individual, the thyroid stimulating hormone (TSH) level may be suppressed, while both total and unbound thyroid hormone levels are increased. In rare cases, there may only be an increase in total triiodothyronine (T3) levels (T3 toxicosis) or an increase in total thyroxine (T4) levels (T4 toxicosis).




Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2939, 2940.

questions.text: Which test distinguishes between organic d/s and functional disorder of Bowel?
questions.solution:
Stool Calprotectin is a marker used to differentiate between IBS and IBD.

  • It is a protein released into the stool by white blood cells when inflammation is present in the intestinal wall. It is elevated in IBD due to the inflammatory process.
  • It is usually normal in IBS, but can occasionally be mildly elevated due to certain food triggers.
  • Fecal calprotectin and lactoferrin levels have been used to distinguish IBD from irritable bowel syndrome (IBS), to assess whether CD is active, and to detect postoperative recurrence of CD.
  • Fecal calprotectin is a more sensitive marker of ileocolonic or colonic inflammation rather than isolated ileal inflammation.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2477.

questions.text: Which of these is not included in the 1° survey of ATLS
questions.solution:
The primary survey of a trauma patient is an assessment that seeks to identify and manage any life-threatening pathologies as soon as possible.
  • This survey follows the ABCDE acronym, which stands for Airway, Breathing, Circulation, Disability, and Exposure.
  • The Airway assessment checks for the patency of the airway and the adequacy of oxygenation or ventilation.
  • The Breathing assessment checks for the adequacy of gas exchange.
  • The Circulation assessment checks for the presence of adequate cardiac output and the presence of any bleeding.
  • The Disability assessment checks for the level of consciousness and neurological function.
  • The Exposure assessment looks for any traumatic injuries or medical issues that may have gone unnoticed during the initial survey.
  • This approach ensures that the most life-threatening issues are identified first and appropriately managed in order to provide the patient with the best chance of survival. CECT has a time consuming process and is not involved in primary survey.
Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 355.

questions.text: Patient had low TSH, however after administering TRH, TSH increased. likely reason?
questions.solution:
• Central Hypothyroidism is a condition of thyroid hormone deficiency caused by a disorder of the pituitary, hypothalamus or the hypothalamic-pituitary portal circulation, resulting in low levels of thyroid stimulating hormone (TSH), thyrotropin-releasing hormone (TRH), or both.
  • Possible causes of TRH deficiency include diseases of the hypothalamus such as benign and malignant tumors, radiation for certain malignancies, infiltrative lesions, infections, traumatic brain injury and stroke.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2932, 2933.

questions.text: A young patient comes to your OPD with the following lesions over the lips. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Diagnosis of herpes labialis is primarily made by visual inspection of the affected area.
  • The most typical presentation is a cluster of small, round, painful vesicles or blisters on a reddened base, often accompanied by painful sores on or near the lips or near the nose.
  • However, diagnosis of herpes labialis can be confirmed more definitively by laboratory tests such as the PCR (polymerase chain reaction) test, the Tzanck test, or a viral culture of lesions.
  • PCR testing is the most accurate, and it can detect the virus even in people who do not have obvious symptoms.
  • The given image shows blisters which indicate herpes labialis but in impetigo yellowish brown crusts would be seen


Reference- Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Page number 25.18
